# Explanatory Memorandum
## No. 131 of 2025
## Regarding the Approval of the Agreement for the Establishment of the Gulf Payments Company and its Articles of Association

In line with the Basic Statute of the Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون</orig>, which calls for achieving closer rapprochement and stronger ties among the Council states, and in pursuit of advanced stages of economic integration through the establishment of similar systems in various fields, including financial payment systems.

This is affirmed by the provisions of the Unified Economic Agreement <orig>الاتفاقية الاقتصادية الموحدة</orig> between the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) states, and in implementation of the resolution of the Supreme Council of the GCC <orig>المجلس الأعلى لمجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> at its 37th session, approving the establishment and development of a system for linking payment systems in the GCC states, by owning and managing the project through the establishment of an independent company owned and valued by the monetary institutions and central banks of the GCC states.

Accordingly, the monetary institutions and central banks of the GCC states signed the Agreement on the Establishment of the Gulf Payments Company <orig>شركة المدفوعات الخليجية</orig> and its Articles of Association <orig>نظامها الأساسي</orig> on 27/3/2019.

This Agreement included sixteen articles and an annex containing the Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>. Article One of the Agreement stipulated the establishment of a closed joint-stock company named (Gulf Payments Company <orig>شركة المدفوعات الخليجية</orig>) with legal personality. Article Two specified the company's main headquarters in Riyadh <orig>الرياض</orig>, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>, and its branch in Abu Dhabi <orig>أبو ظبي</orig>, United Arab Emirates <orig>دولة الإمارات العربية المتحدة</orig>.

Articles Three, Four, and Five, respectively, clarified the company's objectives and mission, participation and ownership in companies, and the company's duration. Article Six specified the authorized capital of this company as one hundred and eighty million Saudi Riyals <orig>ريال سعودي</orig> (SAR 180,000,000), while Article Seven explained the method of subscribing to the company's share capital. Article Eight clarified the responsibility of shareholders, and Articles Nine and Ten of the Agreement addressed the formation of the company's Board of Directors <orig>مجلس إدارة الشركة</orig> and its legal representation.

Article Eleven included provisions for immunity and privileges regarding the company's assets and financial activities, its Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> members, and its employees. Article Twelve explained the methods for settling disputes when they arise between any of the contributing parties in the company or between any of them and the company, the procedures for submitting them to arbitration, and how to form the arbitration panel.

Article Thirteen clarified the company's legal system. Articles Fourteen, Fifteen, and Sixteen addressed the provisions of

# Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>
## Decree-Law No. 131 of 2025
## Approving the Agreement on the Establishment of
## The Gulf Payments Company <orig>شركة المدفوعات الخليجية</orig> and its Articles of Association <orig>نظامها الأساسي</orig>

*   Having reviewed the Constitution,
*   And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD.
*   And Law No. (44) of 1981 approving the Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig> of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) for the Arab States,
*   And Law No. (5) of 2003 approving the Unified Economic Agreement <orig>الاتفاقية الاقتصادية الموحدة</orig> between the GCC states.
*   And based on the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزير الخارجية</orig>.
*   And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>.
*   We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
The Agreement on the Establishment of the Gulf Payments Company <orig>شركة المدفوعات الخليجية</orig> and its Articles of Association <orig>نظامها الأساسي</orig>, signed on 27/3/2019, is hereby approved, and its texts shall be appended to this Decree-Law.

### Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law, which shall come into effect from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

As this agreement serves the interests of the parties and does not conflict with the obligations of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> in the Arab and international spheres, the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig> - in its capacity as the competent authority - as well as the Ministry of Finance <orig>وزارة المالية</orig>, requested that the necessary constitutional procedures be taken for its ratification. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> also requested the preparation of the necessary legal instrument for its enforcement.
Whereas this agreement is considered one of the agreements stipulated in the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, its approval shall therefore be by a law governing this paragraph.
Based on Article Four of the Amiri Decree <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2024/5/10, a draft decree-law approving the aforementioned agreement and its explanatory memorandum has been prepared in the appropriate legal form.
"the Company" and this company shall enjoy legal personality and possess all necessary capacity and powers to achieve its objectives.

## Article Two
### Company Headquarters and Legal Domicile
The Company's main headquarters shall be in the city of Riyadh <orig>الرياض</orig> in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>, and its branch in the city of Abu Dhabi <orig>أبوظبي</orig> in the United Arab Emirates <orig>دولة الإمارات العربية المتحدة</orig>. Branches, offices, or agencies may be established for it inside or outside the Kingdom by a decision of the Company's Board of Directors.

## Article Three
### Company Objectives
First: Company Objectives:
The Company was established to achieve the following objectives:
1. Establishing and building a system for linking payment systems in the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) countries to execute payment transfer and settlement operations among them, without prejudice to the interests of existing payment systems or conflicting with the local policies and procedures of any country.
2. Executing clearing operations according to the mechanism and procedures agreed upon by the monetary institutions and central banks <orig>البنوك المركزية</orig> of the GCC countries.
3. Providing and developing diverse services related to the Gulf payment system.
4. Managing and operating the Gulf payment system.
5. Developing and enhancing joint Gulf payment systems to serve the interests of participating states and their stakeholders, and formulating appropriate strategies to mitigate risks in their various forms, in accordance with international best practices.
6. Establishing a regional infrastructure that serves as the cornerstone for joint regional payment systems among the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) countries, through the following:
    a) Providing a real-time cross-border settlement system for the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) countries.
    b) Supporting transactions in local currencies of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) countries and financial settlement operations between Gulf monetary institutions and central banks <orig>البنوك المركزية</orig>.
    c) Enhancing financial stability by providing an infrastructure that facilitates clearing and settlement of financial operations, which will strengthen the regional market.
    d) Promoting integration among financial markets, ensuring the speed of completing cash transfers, standardizing their format, and guaranteeing their protection, in order to support bilateral and multilateral trade relations.
Second: Company Tasks:

In line with the Articles of Association of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون</orig> calling for closer rapprochement and stronger ties among member states, and in pursuit of advanced stages of economic and financial integration, and to achieve coordination, integration, and interconnectedness among member states in various fields, deepening existing bonds, connections, and aspects of cooperation among their countries, and working to unify their similar systems in various fields, including financial payment systems, which is stipulated in the Economic Agreement <orig>الاتفاقية الاقتصادية</orig> that economic integration among GCC states shall be achieved through gradual steps, starting with the establishment of a Free Trade Area, then a Customs Union, then a Common Market, and culminating in a Monetary and Economic Union, and the establishment of necessary joint companies for this purpose.
And in implementation of the decision of the Supreme Council of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>المجلس الأعلى لمجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>, in its (37th) session, approving the endeavor to build a system for linking payment systems in the GCC countries, the project shall be managed and operated through the establishment of an independent company owned and valued by the monetary institutions and central banks <orig>البنوك المركزية</orig> of the GCC countries.
The monetary institutions and central banks <orig>البنوك المركزية</orig> of the GCC countries have agreed on the following:

## Article One
### Establishment
In accordance with this Agreement and its annexed Articles of Association, a closed joint-stock company named "Gulf Payments Company <orig>شركة المدفوعات الخليجية</orig>" (hereinafter referred to as "the Company") shall be established.

Executing various types of cross-border financial transfers, whether in local currencies or any other foreign currency to be agreed upon later between the participants and approved by the Board of Directors, in accordance with internationally recognized accounting, financial, and banking standards.
2. Cooperating with monetary institutions and Gulf central banks <orig>البنوك المركزية الخليجية</orig> in performing their assigned roles, in a manner that does not conflict with the internal policies and procedures of each state.
3. Providing study and recommendation services on topics related to payment systems.
4. Collecting and preparing statistics related to the Gulf payment system <orig>نظام المدفوعات الخليجي</orig>.
5. Cooperating with international organizations, institutions, and bodies in the field of payment systems and working to enhance the credibility of the Gulf payment system <orig>نظام المدفوعات الخليجي</orig>.
6. Owning and disposing of movable assets and funds, including leasing, renting, and investing, after approval by the Board of Directors.
7. Engaging in similar, complementary, necessary, or related activities to the stated purposes of the company, in line with the company's objectives, and after approval by the company's Board of Directors.
8. The company shall carry out its activities in accordance with this agreement after obtaining the necessary licenses from the competent authorities – if any – in the host country.

## Article Four
### Participation and Ownership in Companies
The company may participate in other companies, and it may also establish limited liability companies or closed joint-stock companies that are consistent with the nature of the company's purposes and tasks, after approval by the company's Board of Directors.

## Article Five
### Company Duration
The company's duration is unlimited – commencing from the date of its registration in the commercial register in the host country.

## Article Six
### Capital
The company's authorized capital is set at one hundred and eighty million Saudi Riyals <orig>ريال سعودي</orig> (180,000,000), divided into eighteen million (18,000,000) shares of equal value and indivisible, each with a value of (10) Saudi Riyals <orig>ريال سعودي</orig>, all of which are ordinary cash shares.

## Article Seven
### Subscription
The founders subscribed to the full capital shares amounting to eighteen million (18,000,000) shares, with a value of one hundred and eighty million Saudi Riyals <orig>ريال سعودي</orig> (180,000,000), of which sixty million Saudi Riyals <orig>ريال سعودي</orig> (60,000,000) has been paid, with the remaining value of the cash shares to be paid on dates determined by the company's Board of Directors. The shares were distributed among the founders as follows:

## Article Eight
### Shareholders' Liability
Shareholders' liability shall be limited to their shares in the company's capital, and no shareholder shall be liable for the company's obligations towards third parties by virtue of their contribution.

## Article Nine
### Company's Board of Directors
The company shall be managed by a Board of Directors consisting of twelve (12) members representing the monetary institutions and central banks <orig>مؤسسات النقد والبنوك المركزية</orig> of the contributing Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> states for a term not exceeding three years.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the founders shall appoint the first Board of Directors for a term of three years. Their roles shall be determined one month after the signing of this agreement. The Board of Directors shall elect a Chairman and a Vice-Chairman at its first meeting, provided that the occupancy of both positions shall be rotational to ensure the participation of all founders.

## Article Ten
### Company Representation
The Chairman of the Board of Directors is the legal representative of the company and represents it before the judiciary, arbitration bodies, and third parties. The Chairman may, by written decision, delegate some of his powers to other members of the Board or company employees to undertake specific tasks or actions. The Vice-Chairman of the Board of Directors shall act in place of the Chairman in his absence.

### Article Eleven
Immunities and Exemptions
First: The Company's Funds and Financial Activities:
1. The Company's funds and assets in the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) states shall not be subject to nationalization, confiscation, or seizure, nor shall they be subject to receivership or attachment, except in execution of a final judicial judgment issued by a competent judicial authority in any of the GCC states.
2. The Company's funds and financial operations shall be exempt from any currency financing restrictions that may be imposed by any of the GCC states.
3. The Company's assets, funds, revenues, and operations stipulated under this Agreement and its attached Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig> shall be exempt from all types of taxes and fees in all GCC states, and from any legally imposed deductions in any of these states. This excludes fees due for services obtained by the Company from any public utility.
Second: Members of the Board of Directors and Company Employees:
1. Members of the Board of Directors shall enjoy immunity from any executive or judicial proceedings related to actions performed in their official capacity or in the course of conducting the Company's business.
2. Members of the Board of Directors and Company employees shall be exempt from any taxes or fees on salaries or remunerations they receive from the Company. They shall be granted travel and residency facilities in the host state and other GCC states to enable them to perform their duties, in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in each state, provided that nothing herein obliges any of the member governments to grant the aforementioned immunities and exemptions to any of its nationals.

### Article Twelve
Dispute Resolution
1. In the event of any dispute arising between any of the contracting parties contributing to the Company, or between any of them and the Company, regarding the interpretation or application of the provisions of this Agreement and its attached Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>, the parties to such dispute shall endeavor to settle it amicably through negotiations. Should negotiations fail within ninety days from the date any party requests to enter into negotiations, the dispute shall be referred to the Commercial Arbitration Center for the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) states, in accordance with the procedures and rules applied by the Center.
2. Notwithstanding what is stated in Clause 1, the parties to the dispute may agree to submit the matters to a single arbitrator appointed by agreement of the parties within a period of thirty days from the date of submission of the notice from the arbitration claimant. If the parties do not agree on this arbitrator, the Secretary-General of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) shall appoint another arbitrator who shall have all the powers and authorities of the arbitration panel.

### Article Thirteen
General Provisions
Legal System of the Company
The provisions contained in this Agreement and its attached Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig> shall apply to the Company and the rights of its shareholders, as an integral part thereof. The provisions of the regulations in force in the host state shall apply to matters not covered by this Agreement and its attached Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>.

### Article Fourteen
Amendment of the Agreement
This Agreement may be amended after the approval of the shareholders, and based on a proposal from any of them. The amendment shall be subject to the same procedures stipulated in Article (15) of this Agreement for its entry into force.

### Article Fifteen
Entry into Force and Ratification of the Agreement
This Agreement shall be ratified in accordance with the procedures followed in each state. This Agreement shall enter into force from the date of deposit of the second state's instrument of ratification with the General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC), and shall be implemented by the ratifying states.

### Article Sixteen
Copies of the Agreement
This Agreement has been drawn up in eight original copies, one copy of which shall be delivered to each party for implementation, another copy shall be kept by the General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> (GCC) states, and another copy shall be kept by the Company.

### Second: Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>
Attached to the Company Establishment Agreement
### Second: Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>
Chapter One
Establishment of the Company

### Article One: Establishment and Company Name
Pursuant to the Establishment Agreement and these Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>, a closed joint-stock company named "Gulf Payments Company <orig>شركة المدفوعات الخليجية</orig>" (hereinafter referred to as "the Company") is hereby established.

### Article Two: Company Headquarters and Legal Domicile
The Company's main headquarters shall be in Riyadh <orig>الرياض</orig>, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>, with internationally recognized property, financial, and banking characteristics.

Article Eight: Share Ownership
Ownership of shares entails acceptance of the provisions of the Articles of Association <orig>اتفاقية التأسيس</orig>, the Company's Bylaws <orig>النظام الأساسي</orig>, and the resolutions of its General Assemblies.

Article Nine: Share Trading:
Shares subscribed by the founders may not be traded until after the publication of financial statements for two financial years, each not less than twelve months from the date of the company's incorporation. The certificates of these shares shall be endorsed to indicate their type, the date of the company's incorporation, and the period during which their trading is prohibited.
The provisions of this Article shall apply to shares subscribed by the founders in the event of a capital increase before the expiry of the prohibition period.

Article Ten: Shareholders' Register:
The company's shares shall be traded by registration in the shareholders' register, which the company prepares or contracts to prepare, and which includes the names of the shareholders, the share numbers, and the paid-up capital. This registration shall be endorsed on the share. The transfer of share ownership shall not be effective against the company or third parties except from the date of registration in the said register.

Article Eleven: Capital Increase:
1. The Extraordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة غير العادية</orig> may decide to increase the company's capital, provided that the capital has been fully paid. The resolution shall specify the method and amount of the capital increase. Shareholders shall have priority to subscribe to the new shares. Shareholders shall be notified of the resolution, their priority, the subscription terms, its duration, and its start and end dates by registered mail...
2. New shares shall be distributed to shareholders who requested subscription, in proportion to the shares they own, provided that what they receive does not exceed what they requested of the new shares. The remaining new shares shall be distributed to shareholders who requested more than their proportion, in proportion to the shares they own, provided that what they receive does not exceed what they requested of the new shares, in accordance with what the Extraordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة غير العادية</orig> decides.

Article Twelve: Capital Reduction:
The Extraordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة غير العادية</orig> may decide to reduce the capital if it exceeds the company's needs or if the company incurs losses. In the latter case alone, the capital may be reduced to below a limit of (to be determined later) Saudi Riyals <orig>ريال سعودي</orig>.

The reduction resolution shall not be issued until after the auditor's report on the reasons for it, the company's obligations, and the effect of the reduction on these obligations has been read. The resolution shall specify the method and amount of the reduction.
If the capital reduction results from it exceeding the company's needs, creditors must be invited to submit their objections within sixty days from the date of publication of the reduction resolution in a daily newspaper distributed in the area where the company's main office is located and in the participating member states. If a creditor objects and submits their documents to the company within the specified time, the company must pay their debt if it is due, or provide sufficient guarantee for its payment if it is deferred.

### Chapter Three
## Company's Board of Directors
### Article Thirteen: Company Management:
The company shall be managed by a Board of Directors <orig>مجلس إدارة</orig> composed of twelve (12) members representing the monetary institutions and central banks of the contributing Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> member states for a period not exceeding three years.
As an exception, the founders shall appoint the first Board of Directors <orig>مجلس إدارة</orig> for a period of three years. The Board of Directors <orig>مجلس إدارة</orig> shall elect a Chairman and a Vice-Chairman at its first meeting, provided that the occupancy of both positions is on a rotational basis to ensure the participation of all founders.

### Article Fourteen: Powers of the Board:
Subject to the powers vested in the General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة</orig>, the Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> shall have the necessary powers to manage the company in a manner that achieves its objectives, and shall, in particular, undertake the following:
1. Formulating the company's basic policies, guidelines, and main objectives, and overseeing their implementation, including:
    a) Developing the company's comprehensive strategy, main business plan, and risk management policy, and reviewing them.
    b) Determining the company's optimal capital structure and financial objectives, preparing annual budgets, and presenting them to the General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة</orig>.
    c)

b) Ensuring the soundness of financial and accounting systems, including systems related to financial reporting.

3. Developing a written policy regulating the relationship with stakeholders to protect them and preserve their rights, including:
(1) Mechanisms for compensating stakeholders in case of violation of their rights as recognized by regulations and protected by contracts.
b) Mechanisms for settling complaints or disputes that may arise between the company and stakeholders.
c) Appropriate mechanisms for establishing good relationships with customers and suppliers and maintaining the confidentiality of information related to them.
d) Professional conduct rules for company employees to ensure compliance with sound professional and ethical standards.
e) Developing policies and procedures that ensure the company's respect for regulations and bylaws and its commitment to disclosing material information to shareholders, creditors, and other stakeholders.
f) Representing the company before public and private entities inside and outside the Kingdom, including various judicial authorities, and deciding to resort to arbitration.
4. Developing a written policy that ensures the secure and smooth management and operation of payment systems, including:
a) Establishing a business continuity plan and a crisis and emergency operations plan.
b) Developing an information security policy and maintaining its confidentiality.
c) Reviewing service level agreements and the extent of compliance therewith.
Article Fifteen: Delegation of Powers.
The Board of Directors may delegate some of its powers to the Chairman or Vice-Chairman.
Article Sixteen: Company Undertakings and Obligations
Board members shall not bear any personal liability regarding the company's undertakings and obligations due to their performance of their duties.
Article Seventeen: Remuneration of Board Members.
The Ordinary General Assembly shall determine the remuneration of a Board member. The Board of Directors' report to the Ordinary General Assembly must include a comprehensive statement of all remuneration, expense allowances, and other benefits received by Board members during the fiscal year. It must also include a statement of what Board members received as employees or administrators, or what they received for technical or administrative work or consultations. Furthermore, it must include a statement of the number of Board meetings and the number of meetings attended by each member since the date of the last General Assembly meeting.
Article Eighteen: Appointment and Powers of the Chairman of the Board of Directors.
1. The Board of Directors shall appoint from among its members a Chairman of the Board and a Vice-Chairman who shall act in his place in his absence or if there is an impediment, on a rotational basis ensuring the participation of all founders. A managing director for the company may be elected from among the members of the company's Board of Directors, provided that he is not a Chief Executive Officer <orig>الرئيس التنفيذي</orig> or General Manager <orig>المدير العام</orig> of another company.
2. The Chairman of the Board of Directors shall be the legal representative of the company before the judiciary and in its relations with third parties.
Article Nineteen: Secretary:
1. The Board of Directors shall have a secretary who is not one of its members.
2. The Board of Directors' secretary shall prepare the minutes of meetings, which shall be signed by the members who attended the session, the secretary, and any member who did not approve a decision taken by the Board may record his objection in the meeting minutes. The signatories of the minutes shall be responsible for the accuracy of the data contained therein, and the Board of Directors shall establish the necessary controls in this regard.
Article Twenty: Chief Executive Officer or General Manager
The Board of Directors may appoint a Chief Executive Officer <orig>الرئيس التنفيذي</orig> or a General Manager <orig>المدير العام</orig> for the company, or several managers or authorized agents, and shall determine their powers, terms of service, salaries, and remunerations. The Chief Executive Officer <orig>الرئيس التنفيذي</orig> or General Manager <orig>المدير العام</orig> of the company may not be a Chief Executive Officer <orig>الرئيس التنفيذي</orig>, General Manager <orig>المدير العام</orig>, or Managing Director <orig>عضواً منتدباً</orig> of another company.
Article Twenty-One: Termination of Board Membership.
Board membership shall terminate upon the expiry of its term, or at the request of the shareholder represented by the member in accordance with the Articles of Association. Nevertheless, the Ordinary General Assembly may at any time dismiss all or some of the Board members, without prejudice to the right of the dismissed member to claim compensation from the company if the dismissal occurred for an unacceptable reason or at an inappropriate time.
A Board member may resign, provided that it is at an appropriate time; otherwise, he shall be liable to the company for any damages resulting from the resignation.
Article Twenty-Two: Vacant Position on the Board.
If a position of a Board member becomes vacant, a replacement member shall be appointed by the shareholder represented by the holder of the vacant position within five working days from the date the position becomes vacant, provided that the appointment is presented to the Ordinary General Assembly at its first meeting. The new member shall complete the term of his predecessor.

  "page_summary": "This page details regulations concerning company meetings, including board of directors' quorum and voting procedures, as well as the powers and functions of the founding general assembly and ordinary and extraordinary general assemblies, covering topics like financial reporting, profit distribution, and capital changes."
}

If the necessary conditions for the Board of Directors' meeting are not met due to the number of its members falling below the stipulated minimum, the remaining members must call for an Ordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة العادية</orig> meeting within sixty days to elect the required number of members.

### Article Twenty-Three: Board Meetings.
The Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> shall meet at least four times a year upon the invitation of its chairman. The invitation shall be sent via registered mail or email. The chairman of the Board may call the Board to a meeting whenever necessary. He must call the Board to a meeting whenever requested by two of its members.

### Article Twenty-Four: Quorum for Board Meetings.
A Board meeting shall not be valid unless attended by (8) members in person, provided that the Chairman or his deputy is among them. A Board member may delegate another member to attend Board meetings according to the following controls:
a. A Board member may not represent more than one member at the same meeting.
b. The delegation must be in writing.
c. The delegate may not vote on resolutions that the regulations prohibit the delegator from voting on.
Board resolutions shall be issued by a majority vote of the members present or represented therein. In case of a tie, the side with which the chairman of the session voted shall prevail.

### Article Twenty-Five: Board Deliberations.
The deliberations and resolutions of the Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> shall be recorded in minutes signed by the chairman of the session, the attending Board members, and the secretary. These minutes shall be entered into a special register signed by the chairman of the Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> and the secretary.

## Chapter Four.

### Article Twenty-Six: Constituent Assembly.
Every subscriber has the right to attend the Constituent Assembly <orig>الجمعية التأسيسية</orig>. A Constituent Assembly <orig>الجمعية التأسيسية</orig> shall convene within forty-five days from the date of the issuance of the incorporation resolution. For the meeting to be valid, a number of subscribers owning or representing by proxy no less than half of the capital must be present. If this quorum is not met, the second meeting shall convene one hour after the expiry of the period specified for the first meeting, provided that the invitation for the first meeting includes this. In all cases, the second meeting shall be valid regardless of the number of attendees.
The meeting shall be chaired by a person elected by the Constituent Assembly <orig>الجمعية التأسيسية</orig> from among the founders. Resolutions of the Constituent Assembly <orig>الجمعية التأسيسية</orig> shall be issued by a majority vote of shareholders owning no less than three-quarters of the shares represented at the meeting.

### Article Twenty-Seven: Powers of the Constituent Assembly.
The Constituent Assembly <orig>الجمعية التأسيسية</orig> shall be competent to consider and decide on the following matters:
1. The founders' report on the company's incorporation procedures and the expenses incurred.
2. The founders' actions related to the company during the incorporation period.
3. Approval of the company's incorporation and the announcement of the commencement of its operations.
4. Election of the members of the first Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> if they have not been appointed by the founders.
5. Appointment of the company's first auditor if not already appointed in the company's incorporation agreement.

### Article Twenty-Eight: Powers of the Ordinary General Assembly.
The General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة</orig> shall convene with one representative from each of the contracting parties. The General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة</orig> shall convene in the host country, and may convene outside the host country by a resolution of the Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig>. The Ordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة العادية</orig> shall be competent in the following:
1. The Board of Directors' <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> report on the company's activities and financial position during the year, and the auditor's report.
2. The company's balance sheet and profit and loss statement.
3. Election of Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> members when necessary.
4. Appointment of auditors and determination of their fees.
5. Board of Directors' <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> proposals regarding profit distribution.
6. Board of Directors' <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> proposals regarding Board members' remuneration and its determination.
7. Discharging Board of Directors <orig>مجلس الإدارة</orig> members from liability, or dismissing them and filing liability lawsuits against them, as the case may be.
8. Discharging auditors from liability, or dismissing them and filing liability lawsuits against them, as the case may be. The Ordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة العادية</orig> shall convene at least once a year during the six months following the end of the company's financial year, and other Ordinary General Assemblies <orig>الجمعية العامة العادية</orig> may be called whenever necessary.

### Article Twenty-Nine: Powers of the Extraordinary General Assembly:
The provisions related to the Ordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة العادية</orig> shall apply to the Extraordinary General Assembly <orig>الجمعية العامة غير العادية</orig>, taking into account the following provisions:
1. Amendment of the company's Articles of Association.
2. Increase or decrease of capital.
3. Dissolution of the company or its merger into another company.
4. Sale of the project undertaken by the company or its disposal in any other manner.

## Article Thirty: Calling of Assemblies.

The Ordinary and Extraordinary General Assemblies of shareholders shall be convened upon an invitation from the Board of Directors. The Board of Directors must call for an Ordinary General Assembly meeting if requested by the auditor <orig>مراجع الحسابات</orig>, the audit committee <orig>لجنة التدقيق</orig>, or international representatives from member states representing shares not less than one-third of the company's shares. The auditor <orig>مراجع الحسابات</orig> may call for the assembly to convene if the Board fails to call the assembly within thirty days from the date of the auditor's <orig>مراجع الحسابات</orig> request.
Shareholders shall be invited to the Ordinary General Assembly meeting at least ten days prior to the scheduled date, by registered mail or email.

## Article Thirty-One: Attendance Register of Assemblies.

Shareholders wishing to attend the Ordinary or Extraordinary General Assembly shall register their names via the email specified by the company, prior to the scheduled time of the assembly.

## Article Thirty-Two: Quorum for the Ordinary General Assembly Meeting.

The Ordinary General Assembly meeting shall not be valid unless attended by shareholders representing at least half of the company's capital.
If the necessary quorum for this meeting is not met, a second meeting shall be held within a period not exceeding thirty days from the date scheduled for the first meeting. In all cases, the second meeting shall be valid regardless of the number of shares represented therein.

## Article Thirty-Three: Quorum for the Extraordinary General Assembly Meeting.

The Extraordinary General Assembly meeting shall not be valid unless attended by shareholders representing at least three-quarters of the capital. If this quorum is not met in the first meeting, a second meeting shall be held within a period not exceeding thirty days from the date scheduled for the first meeting, provided that the invitation for the first meeting includes an announcement of the possibility of holding this meeting. In this case, the second meeting shall be valid if attended by those representing more than half of the capital.
If the necessary quorum is not met in the second meeting, an invitation shall be issued for a third meeting to be held after thirty days from the date of the second meeting. The third meeting shall be valid regardless of the number of attendees, and the assembly's decisions in the latter case shall not be effective except after the approval of the competent authorities <orig>الجهات المختصة</orig> in the host country <orig>دولة المقر</orig>.

## Article Thirty-Four: Voting in Assemblies.

Each subscriber <orig>مكتتب</orig> shall have one vote for each share they represent in the Constituent Assembly <orig>الجمعية التأسيسية</orig>, and each shareholder shall have one vote for each share in the General Assembly meetings.

## Article Thirty-Five: Resolutions of Assemblies.

Resolutions in the Constituent Assembly <orig>الجمعية التأسيسية</orig> shall be issued by an absolute majority of the shares represented therein. Resolutions of the Ordinary General Assembly shall be issued by an absolute majority of the shares represented in the meeting, and resolutions of the Extraordinary General Assembly shall be issued by a two-thirds majority of the shares represented in the meeting.

## Article Thirty-Six: Discussion in Assemblies.

Each shareholder has the right to discuss the topics listed on the assembly's agenda and to direct questions regarding them to the members of the Board of Directors and the auditor <orig>مراجع الحسابات</orig>. The Board of Directors or the auditor <orig>مراجع الحسابات</orig> shall answer shareholders' questions to the extent that it does not harm the company's interest. If a shareholder deems the answer to their question unsatisfactory, they shall refer the matter to the assembly, and its decision in this regard shall be final and enforceable.

## Article Thirty-Seven: Chairing of Assemblies and Preparation of Minutes.

The meetings of the General Assemblies of shareholders shall be chaired by the Chairman of the Board of Directors, or his deputy in his absence, or by a member delegated by the Board of Directors for this purpose in the absence of both the Chairman and his deputy.
Minutes of the assembly meeting shall be prepared, including the number of shareholders present or represented, the number of shares held by them in person or by proxy, the number of votes allocated to them, the resolutions adopted, the number of votes for and against them, and a comprehensive summary of the discussions that took place during the meeting.
The minutes shall be regularly recorded after each meeting in a special register signed by the chairman of the assembly, its secretary, and the vote counter.

### Chapter Five
### Audit Committee

## Article Thirty-Eight: Formation of the Audit Committee.

An audit committee <orig>لجنة تدقيق</orig> consisting of five members, who are not members of the Board of Directors, whether shareholders or others, shall be formed by a decision of the Board of Directors. The decision shall specify the committee's tasks, operating controls, and members' remuneration.

## Article Thirty-Nine: Quorum for the Audit Committee Meeting.

For the audit committee <orig>لجنة التدقيق</orig> meeting to be valid, the majority of its members must be present. Its decisions shall be issued by the votes of those present, and in case of a tie, the side with which the committee chairman voted shall prevail.

## Article Forty: Powers of the Audit Committee.

The audit committee <orig>لجنة التدقيق</orig> is responsible for overseeing the company's operations. To this end, it has the right to inspect its records and documents and to request any clarification or statement from the members of the Board of Directors or the executive management.
It may request the Board of Directors to call for a General Assembly meeting of the company if the Board of Directors obstructs its work or if the company suffers significant damages or losses.

### Article Forty-Six: Profit Distribution

The Company's annual net profits shall be distributed as follows:
1- Annually, (10%) of the net profits must be allocated to form the Company's statutory reserve.
The Ordinary General Assembly may decide to cease this allocation when the said reserve reaches (30%) of the paid-up capital.
2 The Ordinary General Assembly may, based on a proposal from the Board of Directors, allocate (10%) of the net profits to form a contractual reserve designated for specific purposes.
3- The Ordinary General Assembly may decide to form other reserves, to the extent that serves the Company's interest or ensures the distribution of stable profits as much as possible to shareholders.
The Ordinary General Assembly shall, after the commencement of operations and upon achieving profits, determine the profit percentage for each participant. It shall also determine the profit percentages in subsequent years in a manner that benefits the participants and does not harm the Company's interests and stability, taking into account the provisions stipulated in Article Seventeen of these Articles of Association <orig>النظام</orig>. The Ordinary General Assembly shall later determine the remuneration of the Board of Directors' members.

### Article Forty-Seven: Entitlement to Profits

A shareholder is entitled to their share of profits in accordance with the resolution of the General Assembly issued in this regard.
The resolution shall specify the entitlement date and the distribution date, and the right to profits shall belong to the shareholders registered in the shareholders' records at the end of the specified entitlement day.

### Article Forty-One: Audit Committee Reports

The Audit Committee <orig>لجنة التدقيق</orig> shall review the Company's financial statements and the reports and observations submitted by the auditor, and express its views thereon, if any. It shall also prepare a report on its opinion regarding the adequacy of the Company's internal control system and on other work it has performed within its scope of competence. The Board of Directors must deposit sufficient copies of this report at the Company's head office at least ten days before the date of the General Assembly meeting, provided that shareholders are supplied with a copy thereof. The report shall be read during the General Assembly meeting.

## Chapter Six

### Auditors.
### Article Forty-Two: Appointment of Auditors.

The Company must have one or more auditors from among the auditors licensed to operate in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>, appointed annually by the Ordinary General Assembly. Their remuneration and term of service shall be determined, provided that the term of the appointed auditor does not exceed three years, renewable for a maximum of five consecutive years. A period of two years must elapse before re-engaging the same auditor once the five-year period is completed. The General Assembly may also change the auditor at any time, without prejudice to their right to compensation if the change occurs at an inappropriate time or for an unlawful reason.

### Article Forty-Three: Powers of Auditors

The auditor has the right at any time to inspect the Company's books, records, and other documents, and also to request data and clarifications deemed necessary to verify the Company's assets, liabilities, and other matters falling within the scope of their work. The Chairman of the Board of Directors and the Company's Executive Management must enable the auditor to perform their duty. If the auditor encounters difficulty in this regard, they shall record it in a report submitted to the Board of Directors. If the Board and Executive Management do not facilitate the auditor's work, the auditor must call for an Ordinary General Assembly meeting to consider the matter.

## Chapter Seven

### Company Accounts and Profit Distribution.
### Article Forty-Four: Financial Year:

The Company's financial year shall begin on the first of January and end on the last day of December of each year, provided that the first financial year begins from the date of its registration in the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig> until the end of December of the following year.

### Article Forty-Five: Financial Documents

1- At the end of each financial year of the Company, the Board of Directors must prepare the Company's financial statements and a report on its activities and financial position for the year.

## Article Forty-Eight: Company Losses.
If the company's losses reach half of the paid-up capital at any time during the financial year, any official in the company or the auditor must immediately inform the Chairman of the Board of Directors upon becoming aware of this. The Chairman of the Board of Directors must immediately inform the board members. The Board of Directors, within fifteen days of becoming aware of this, must call for an extraordinary general assembly meeting within forty-five days from the date of its knowledge of the losses, to decide either to increase the company's capital or reduce it in accordance with the provisions of these Articles of Association <orig>هذا النظام</orig> to the extent that the percentage of losses falls below half of the paid-up capital, or to dissolve the company.

## Chapter Eight
### Dissolution and Liquidation of the Company.
## Article Forty-Nine: Expiration of the Company.
Upon its expiration, the company shall immediately enter the liquidation phase and retain its legal personality to the extent necessary for liquidation. The decision for voluntary liquidation shall be issued by the extraordinary general assembly. The liquidation decision must include the appointment of the liquidator, the definition of their powers, fees, the restrictions imposed on their powers, and the duration of the liquidation. The duration of voluntary liquidation must not exceed five years and may not be extended beyond that except by a court order. The authority of the company's Board of Directors terminates upon its dissolution; however, these individuals shall remain in charge of managing the company and shall be considered, with respect to third parties, as liquidators until a liquidator is appointed. Shareholder assemblies shall remain in existence during the liquidation period, and their role shall be limited to exercising their competencies that do not conflict with the liquidator's competencies.

Article (8) clarified that the application and interpretation of the provisions of this Agreement shall be based on relevant international agreements concerning immunities and privileges granted to international organizations and their personnel. Article (9) stipulated the method for settling disputes arising from the interpretation and implementation of this Agreement. Article (10) included procedures for entry into force, amendment, and termination, whereby it shall enter into force from the date of the last notification by which the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> informs the General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> that it has completed all necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force. It may be amended by mutual consent of the two parties, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article. This Agreement may be applied provisionally after its signing in accordance with the provisions of Article (25) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties of 1969. This Agreement shall remain in force for an indefinite period unless one of the parties notifies the other party of its intention to terminate it in writing and through diplomatic channels six months prior to its termination date.
Since this Agreement serves the interest of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and does not conflict with its obligations in the Arab and international spheres, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> requested the preparation of the necessary legal instrument for its ratification.
Whereas this Agreement, according to its provisions, requires ratification by law in accordance with the text of the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, its approval shall therefore be by law pursuant to the provision of this paragraph.
Based on Article Four of the Amiri Decree <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2024/5/10, the draft Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> necessary for its approval, along with its explanatory memorandum, has been prepared in the appropriate legal format.
Therefore, the attached draft Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> for its approval, along with its explanatory memorandum, has been prepared.

### Explanatory Memorandum
For Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> No. 132 of 2025
Approving the Headquarters Agreement
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>
Regarding the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig>
For the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج</orig>
Based on the Agreement establishing the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig>, signed in Abu Dhabi <orig>أبو ظبي</orig> on 1976/1/4, in light of the State of Kuwait's <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> approval to host the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig> of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>, and out of the desire of both parties to establish the necessary rules for the headquarters of the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig> of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and enable it to carry out its assigned tasks and responsibilities to the fullest extent.
Therefore, on 2024/11/14, a Headquarters Agreement <orig>اتفاقية مقر</orig> was signed between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> regarding the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig> of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج</orig>.
Article (1) addressed the definitions of the terms contained therein and the interpretation of their meanings. Article (2) clarified the purpose of the Agreement, which is to enable the Institution to carry out its assigned tasks and responsibilities to the fullest extent and to specify the privileges and immunities it enjoys. Article (3) clarified the legal personality of the Institution and its affiliation with the General Secretariat <orig>الأمانة العامة</orig> and the decisions applicable to it. Article (4) referred to the facilities provided by the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, whereby the Government is committed to granting a headquarters to the Institution in accordance with the procedures in force in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>. Article (5) clarified communications and correspondence, stating that no censorship may be imposed on the official communications and correspondence of the Institution, and the Institution has the right to install wired and wireless communication devices to perform its work and is exempt from all related fees and expenses.
Article (6) clarified the immunity of the Institution, whereby the Government shall take all necessary measures to protect the building and prevent its intrusion, material damage, breach of its security, or undermining of its dignity, provided that the Institution's premises are not used for purposes inconsistent with its powers and objectives. The Article also stipulated tax exemptions for the headquarters' funds and prohibited the use of the headquarters building for asylum by any person, especially those legally convicted of crimes they committed or those fleeing justice. It also specified the immunities of the Director General <orig>المدير العام</orig>, the Institution's employees and their families, and representatives of member states.
Article (7) specified the exceptions, stating that nothing in the provisions of this Agreement shall be interpreted as implying any infringement of the right of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to take such measures as it deems appropriate to protect its security, safety, or the integrity of the system.

### Headquarters Agreement
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
And the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>
Regarding the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig> of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>
The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, as the Host State, and the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>, represented by the General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>الأمانة العامة لمجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>, hereinafter referred to as "the Two Parties",
Based on the Agreement establishing the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig>, signed in Abu Dhabi <orig>أبو ظبي</orig> on 3 Muharram 1396 AH, corresponding to 4 January 1976 AD,
And whereas the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> has agreed to host the Joint Program Production Institution <orig>مؤسسة الإنتاج البرامجي المشترك</orig> of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>,

-2 Provide all necessary facilities for the Organization and secure the necessary public utilities and services for it, such as postal, telephone, and communication services in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement, in addition to electricity, water, and fire prevention services.

Article Five
Communications and Correspondence
-1 No censorship shall be imposed on the official communications and correspondence of the Organization. The Organization shall have the right to use codes in its correspondence and communications, and it shall also have the right to use all necessary means of communication, including diplomatic bags.
-2 The Organization shall have the right to install wired and wireless communication devices for the performance of its work, establish ports, and introduce the necessary equipment for carrying out its work, provided that the necessary approvals are obtained for this.
-3 The Organization shall be exempt from all related fees and expenses.

Article Six
Immunities and Privileges
Without prejudice to the provisions of the Agreement on Privileges and Immunities of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> for the Arab States, signed in Riyadh <orig>الرياض</orig> on 9 Jumada al-Akhira 1404 AH, corresponding to March 11, 1984 AD, the headquarters of the Director General <orig>المدير العام</orig> and the Organization's staff who are not citizens or residents of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> shall enjoy the following immunities and privileges:

Firstly: Immunities of the Headquarters:
-1 The inviolability of the headquarters shall be protected and shall not be infringed upon. No judicial or administrative measures may be taken against it. Furthermore, no employee or person holding any public authority in the government may enter the headquarters to carry out any duty related to their position except with explicit written permission from the Director General <orig>المدير العام</orig> and under the conditions he approves. In case of necessity, serious reasons must be present for entering the Organization.
-2 The Government shall take all necessary measures to protect the headquarters and prevent its intrusion, material damage, breach of security, or undermining of its dignity, provided that the Organization's buildings are not used for purposes inconsistent with its powers and objectives.
-3 The archives and documents of the Organization shall be inviolable.
-4 The Organization shall have the right to raise the flag and emblem of the General Secretariat <orig>الأمانة العامة</orig> and the flags of the GCC <orig>مجلس التعاون</orig> member states on its buildings.
-5 Under no circumstances shall the headquarters be used to grant asylum to any person, especially those legally convicted of crimes they committed, those fleeing justice, those wanted for arrest, or those sentenced to deportation outside the country.

And with the desire of both parties to establish the necessary rules for the headquarters of the Joint Program Production Institution of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> for the Arab States in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, enabling it to fully carry out the tasks and responsibilities entrusted to it, and to achieve the noble objectives of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> for the Arab States and the purposes for which the Organization was established,
The two parties have agreed as follows:

Article One
Definitions
For the purpose of applying the provisions of this Agreement, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated opposite each of them, unless the context of the text requires otherwise:
- The Government: The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>.
- The GCC <orig>مجلس التعاون</orig>: The Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> for the Arab States.
- The General Secretariat <orig>الأمانة العامة</orig>: The General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> for the Arab States.
- The Secretary General <orig>الأمين العام</orig>: The Secretary General of the GCC <orig>مجلس التعاون</orig>.
- The Organization: The Joint Program Production Institution of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> for the Arab States.
- The Director General <orig>المدير العام</orig>: The Director General of the Organization.
- Organization Staff: All employees working in the Organization.
- The Headquarters: The Organization's building, including all buildings, parts of buildings, and attached lands occupied by the Organization and designated for its purposes, whether the Organization owns, leases, or occupies them in any other capacity.
- Organization Funds: All assets, funds, balances, deposits, and bank accounts managed by the Organization to achieve its objectives.

Article Two
Purpose of the Agreement
Without prejudice to the laws and regulations applicable in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, this Agreement aims to enable the Organization to fully carry out the tasks and responsibilities entrusted to it and to clarify the privileges and immunities it enjoys.

Article Three
Legal Personality
The Organization shall enjoy legal personality and shall have the capacity to contract, dispose of real, movable, and immovable property, litigate, and take all necessary legal actions to exercise this capacity.
The Organization shall be subordinate to the General Secretariat <orig>الأمانة العامة</orig> and under its authority and supervision in accordance with its applicable regulations (laws) and decisions.

Article Four
Facilities Provided by the State of Kuwait
The Government undertakes the following:
-1 Grant a headquarters to the Organization in accordance with the procedures and mechanisms in force in the State of

7- The Organization, its movable and immovable assets, its income, and its other properties shall be exempt from all taxes. This exemption shall not include fees collected for the use of public facilities or in exchange for public services. The Organization shall also be exempt from customs duties, regulations, and restrictions imposed on the export and import of materials that the Organization exports or imports for its official use. The Organization may also bring funds, securities, and foreign currencies into the State of Kuwait or transfer them to another country.
Second: Immunities of the Director General <orig>المدير العام</orig>, Organization Staff, and their Families:
1- Freedom of movement and passage within the territory of the State, subject to the laws, regulations, and instructions concerning prohibited or restricted areas for reasons related to national security.
2- Judicial immunity for all statements, writings, or actions made by them in their official capacity. This immunity shall remain in effect even after the cessation of their official capacity with respect to what was issued by them in the aforementioned capacity.
3- Immunity from arrest, detention, confiscation of personal luggage, vehicles, documents, manuscripts, all personal belongings, and intrusion into private residences.
4- Exemption from tax on salaries and remunerations received from the General Secretariat <orig>الأمانة العامة</orig>.
5- The right for them and their family members to obtain necessary residency and to facilitate their return to their home countries in times of crisis.
Third: Representatives of Member States:
1- Permanent missions and delegations <orig>البعثات والوفود الدائمة</orig> and their members, and representatives of committees <orig>اللجان</orig> to the Member States <orig>الدول الأعضاء</orig> of the Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون</orig>, who are invited by the Organization to carry out official duties or to hold training courses during their performance of duties related to the Organization and their travel to and return from the meeting venue, shall enjoy the same privileges and immunities stipulated in this Article.
2- The General Secretariat <orig>الأمانة العامة</orig> shall inform the Government of the names, ranks, duties, and dates of arrival and departure of these persons in a timely manner.

### Article Seven
**Exceptions**
Nothing in the provisions of this Agreement shall be interpreted as implying any derogation from the right of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to take such measures as it deems appropriate to protect its security, safety, or the safety of public order within its territory in emergency and exceptional circumstances that the State deems to exist.

### Article Eight
**Application and Interpretation of the Agreement**
In matters not specifically provided for in this Agreement, or in the Agreement on Privileges and Immunities of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> signed in Riyadh on 9 Jumada al-Akhira 1404 AH corresponding to 11 March 1984 AD, the provisions of this Agreement shall be applied and interpreted based on relevant international agreements concerning the privileges and immunities accorded to international organizations and their personnel in general.

### Article Nine
**Settlement of Disputes**
Any dispute that may arise concerning the interpretation or application of this Agreement shall be settled between the two parties through diplomatic channels <orig>القنوات الدبلوماسية</orig> and through consultations and negotiations.

### Article Ten
**Entry into Force, Amendment, Repeal**
1- This Agreement shall enter into force from the date of the notification by which the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> informs the General Secretariat of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> of its completion of all necessary constitutional procedures <orig>الإجراءات الدستورية</orig> for its entry into force.
2- This Agreement may be amended by mutual consent of the parties, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
3- This Agreement may be applied provisionally after its signature and in accordance with the provisions of Article (25) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties of 1969.
4- This Agreement shall remain in force for an indefinite period, unless one of the parties notifies the other party of its intention to terminate it in writing and through diplomatic channels <orig>القنوات الدبلوماسية</orig> six months prior to its termination date.
This Agreement was drawn up in Kuwait City on 12 Jumada al-Awwal 1446 AH corresponding to 14 November 2024 AD, in two original copies in the Arabic language, each having equal legal validity.

## Decree by Law No. 133 of 2025
Amending Some Provisions of the Code of Civil and Commercial Procedure
Issued by Decree by Law No. 38 of 1980
- Having reviewed the Constitution
- And Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH corresponding to
10 May 2024 AD
- And Law No. (17) of 1973 regarding Judicial Fees,
as amended by Decree by Law No. (78) of 2025,
- And the Code of Civil and Commercial Procedure <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> issued by Decree by Law
No. (38) of 1980, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (39) of 1980 regarding Evidence in Civil
and Commercial Matters, and its amending laws,
- And Decree by Law No. (20) of 1981 establishing a circuit <orig>دائرة</orig>
within the General Court <orig>المحكمة الكلية</orig> to hear administrative disputes, amended by Law No. 61 of
1982, and Decree by Law No. 94 of 2024,
- And the Law Regulating Expertise <orig>قانون تنظيم الخبرة</orig> issued by Decree by Law No. (40) of
1980, and its amending laws,
- And the Law Regulating the Judiciary <orig>قانون تنظيم القضاء</orig> issued by Decree by Law No. (23) of
1990, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. 30 of 2002 approving the Convention for the Unification
of Certain Rules for International Carriage by Air, signed in Montreal on
28/5/1999,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Justice,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,
- We have issued the following Decree by Law:
### Article One
The texts of Articles (40, 45 bis, 106, 108 and 109)
of the aforementioned Code of Civil and Commercial Procedure <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> shall be replaced with the following texts:
### Article (40):
(( If the lawsuit is for the validity, annulment, or rescission of a contract, its value shall be estimated
by the value of the subject matter of the contract. For exchange contracts, the lawsuit shall be valued at the
greater of the two exchanged values.
If the lawsuit is for the validity, annulment, rescission,
or termination of a continuous contract, the estimation shall be based on the total monetary consideration for the entire duration of the contract. If the said contract has been partially executed, the lawsuit for its
rescission shall be estimated based on the remaining duration.
If the lawsuit is for eviction or delivery of real estate, the estimation shall be according to the rules specified in the preceding paragraph. For a lawsuit concerning the extension of a contract, its
estimation shall be based on the monetary consideration for the period over which the dispute regarding the contract's extension arose )).
### Article (45) bis:
(( It is permissible to resort to the electronic litigation system <orig>نظام التقاضي الإلكتروني</orig> specific to the court clerk's office <orig>إدارة كتاب المحكمة</orig> and using an approved electronic signature. This system
includes filing lawsuits and appeals against judgments, paying fees, submitting documents,
depositing and reviewing memoranda and documents, exchanging them, serving
judicial papers, and courts holding their sessions electronically remotely using
visual and audio electronic communication technology between the parties to the lawsuit,
and the issuance of judgments and orders and their enforcement procedures. Data issued
from electronic systems shall be considered as the original where the law requires direct
action on the original document.
A (Lawsuit or Appeal Preparation Office) <orig>مكتب تهيئة الدعوى أو الطعن</orig> may be established in each court, as
appropriate, which shall – before presenting the lawsuit or appeal to the circuit – examine
the requests, lawsuits, and appeals submitted through the electronic litigation system
to verify the completeness of their data and documents and their registration in this system,
and until the scheduled session date.
The regulation for the electronic litigation system <orig>لائحة نظام التقاضي الإلكتروني</orig> shall be issued by a decision of the Minister of Justice, specifying
the rules and provisions to be followed in this regard. It may include – when
necessary – the rules and provisions related to the establishment of a (Lawsuit
or Appeal Preparation Office) <orig>مكتب تهيئة الدعوى أو الطعن</orig>, as appropriate, and its mechanism of operation, all while observing the provisions of
this law that regulate these procedures and what is consistent with this system )).
### Article (106):
(( If a judge has a reason for recusal and does not withdraw, the litigant may request his recusal.
The recusal shall be effected by a report filed with the court clerk's office <orig>إدارة الكتاب</orig>, signed by the applicant himself or his agent
authorized by a special power of attorney. The power of attorney shall be attached to the report. The
recusal report must include its reasons and be accompanied by any supporting documents.
The applicant for recusal must deposit, upon submitting the report,
a guarantee amount of two hundred Dinars. The guarantee shall be multiplied by the number of judges whose recusal is requested. It is also permissible to request assignment if the preliminary judgment rejected the recusal request and it was appealed. ))

## Article Two

The phrase (one hundred dinars) mentioned in the text of Article (53) of the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> shall be replaced with the phrase (two hundred dinars).

The phrase (not less than twenty dinars and not more than one hundred dinars) mentioned in the text of Articles (69) first paragraph, and (70) / first paragraph of the aforementioned Law shall be replaced with the phrase (not less than fifty dinars and not more than one hundred and fifty dinars).
The phrase (one hundred dinars) mentioned in the text of Articles (76) and (136) paragraph (second) of the aforementioned Law shall be replaced with the phrase (two hundred dinars).
The phrase (twenty dinars) shall be replaced with the phrase (fifty dinars), and the phrase (fifty dinars) shall be replaced with the phrase (one hundred dinars) mentioned in the text of Article (137) second paragraph of the aforementioned Law.
The phrase (twenty dinars) shall be replaced with the phrase (fifty dinars), and the phrase (150 / paragraph (second) of the aforementioned Law.
The phrase (twenty dinars) shall be replaced with the phrase (fifty dinars), and the phrase (and fifty dinars) shall be replaced with the phrase (one hundred dinars) mentioned in the text of Article (159) third paragraph of the aforementioned Law.
The phrase (fifty dinars) shall be replaced with the phrase (one hundred dinars) mentioned in the text of Article (187 / third paragraph of the aforementioned Law.
The phrase (thirty dinars) mentioned in the text of Article (211) second paragraph of the aforementioned Law shall be replaced with the phrase (fifty dinars).

## Article Three

A final paragraph shall be added to the text of Article (107) of the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig>, and two new articles numbered (43) bis and (109 bis) shall be added to this Law, with their texts as follows:
their recusal. The court registry <orig>إدارة الكتاب</orig> shall not accept the recusal report unless it is accompanied by proof of deposit of the guarantee. The deposit of a single guarantee for each judge is sufficient in the event of multiple applicants for recusal if they submit their request in one report, even if the grounds for recusal differ.
The court shall rule against the applicant for recusal, upon rejection of the recusal request, or forfeiture of the right thereto, or its inadmissibility, or its nullity, with a fine of not less than five hundred dinars and not more than one thousand dinars. The fine shall be multiplied by the number of judges requested to be recused, and the guarantee shall be confiscated in these cases by operation of law.))

## Article (108):

((The court registry <orig>إدارة الكتاب</orig> must submit the recusal report to the President of the Court. If the person requested to be recused is the President, the report shall be submitted to his deputy. The person to whom the report is submitted must immediately inform the judge requested to be recused of the report.
The judge must respond in writing to the facts and grounds of recusal within two working days following his notification. If he does not respond within this period or admits the grounds for recusal, and these grounds are legally sufficient for recusal, the President of the Court shall issue an order for his withdrawal.
If the judge responds to the grounds for recusal but does not admit a ground legally sufficient for his recusal, the person to whom the report was submitted shall designate the circuit responsible for considering the recusal and set a date for its urgent consideration before it. The court registry <orig>إدارة الكتاب</orig> must notify the applicant for recusal and the judge of this date, and also notify the other litigants in the original case to submit any recusal requests they may have in accordance with the preceding article. The said circuit must investigate the recusal request in the consultation chamber, then rule after hearing the statements of the applicant for recusal and the observations of the judge when necessary or if requested. In the investigation of the recusal request, the judge may not be interrogated or sworn in.
The President of the Court – or his deputy – as the case may be – in the event of submitting recusal requests before the closure of pleadings in the first recusal request, must refer these requests to the same circuit considering that request to rule on all of them with a single judgment.
The proceedings for the recusal request must be continued and decided upon, even if the applicant decides to withdraw it. The judgment on the recusal request shall be issued in a public session within a period not exceeding one month from the date of its consideration before the court.))
