The value of the national currency of a contracting state member of the International Monetary Fund <orig>صندوق النقد الدولي</orig> denominated in Special Drawing Rights <orig>حقوق السحب الخاصة</orig> units shall be calculated according to the valuation method applied by the International Monetary Fund <orig>صندوق النقد الدولي</orig>). Article (55) of the Convention also stipulated that (this Convention shall supersede any rules applicable to international air transport ....), meaning that the provisions of this Convention have become a special law among the laws of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, obliging the courts to implement the rules contained therein. And since civil liability claims filed against air carriers have steadily increased, and the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> did not contain a clear criterion for determining the value of such claims when filed.

Since the principle of judicial impartiality is based on a fundamental rule, which is the necessity for the litigant to be confident in their judge and that their judgment is issued solely based on truth, without bias or personal inclination. Legislative texts regulating judicial affairs have affirmed and provided for this principle, and at the same time allowed the litigant, if they have serious evidence of a suspicion of influencing this impartiality, a way to prevent the person against whom such suspicion arose from adjudicating their case. Consequently, their right to recuse a judge from hearing a specific dispute has been established as one of the fundamental rights linked to the right to litigate itself, and reality has revealed

### Article (107), Last Paragraph:
((It is not permissible to re-request the recusal of the same judge in the case)).

### Article (43) bis:
((The value of compensation claims resulting from civil liability filed against the air carrier shall be estimated in terms of Special Drawing Rights <orig>حقوق السحب الخاصة</orig> units, equivalent to their value in Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig> according to the valuation approved by the International Monetary Fund <orig>صندوق النقد الدولي</orig> on the day the claim is filed. Any change in the value of the units occurring after the claim is filed shall not be included in this estimation)).

### Article (109) bis:
((The submission of any other recusal request, whether from the initial party requesting recusal or other parties, shall not result in the suspension of the original case. Nevertheless, the court considering the recusal request may – upon the request of one of the parties – order the suspension of proceedings in the original case, and in this instance, the provision of the preceding article shall apply)).

Therefore, it was deemed necessary to address this deficiency by establishing the legal basis for a comprehensive electronic litigation system, with the possibility of enhancing it through the creation of a case or appeal preparation office, as appropriate, in each court. This office would be tasked with directly handling the preparatory tasks for the electronic file from the moment of its registration until the date of the first hearing, including examining data, completing any missing documents, registering them in that system, and communicating with the parties via digital means to inform them of matters related to their litigation. It is noted that the electronic litigation system is an optional means; for litigants, it is not a substitute for their traditional litigation. Its benefits became apparent during the international (Corona) pandemic, and the accompanying issuance of practical decisions and official statistics regarding the excessive recourse to recusal requests by some litigants who wish to prolong litigation and use it as a means of malice and obstinacy in the dispute without merit, which leads to harming judges' reputation, status, and feelings, and casting doubt on their integrity and impartiality by the adversaries, without the existing legislative texts being sufficient to address this.
Given that many years have passed since the issuance of the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig>, most of its provisions specifying amounts for guarantees or penalties have not been amended, despite the economic changes that have occurred during the past years, including the rise in inflation rates, individual income levels, currency exchange rate fluctuations, and the decrease in purchasing power. The original principle regarding the legislator's authority in regulating rights is discretionary, unless restricted by the Constitution with specific controls. The danger lies in differentiation among individuals concerning their right to access their natural judge or within the scope of procedural or substantive rules governing judicial disputes regarding claimed rights. It should always be that a single dispute has a single set of rules, whether in the context of claiming rights, defending them, or appealing judgments issued therein. The purpose of the guarantees stipulated in the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> was to provide a new assurance for individuals in exercising their right to litigation, whether by filing lawsuits or appealing judgments issued therein.
Given that electronic litigation has numerous advantages in achieving speed of procedures, saving time and effort, and reducing expenses, thereby allowing litigants to attend electronic court hearings remotely.
For all the foregoing reasons, and since the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024, and Article (4) thereof stipulated that laws shall be issued by decree-laws, it was deemed appropriate to prepare the present draft decree-law to introduce amendments to the provisions of the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> to keep pace with all the aforementioned developments.
Article One of the draft stipulated the replacement of Articles (40, 45), 106 bis, 108, and (109) of the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> with other texts that explicitly provide for the estimation of the value of a lawsuit if it is filed requesting the termination of a continuous contract, the eviction of a property, or its handover. Consequently, it was deemed appropriate to replace the text of Article (40) with another text, which clarified in the substituted paragraphs that if the lawsuit is for the validity, annulment, rescission, or termination of a contract, the estimation shall be based on the total monetary consideration for the entire duration of the contract. If the said contract has been partially executed, the lawsuit shall be estimated

It goes without saying that the newly established (Office for the Preparation of Lawsuits or Appeals <orig>مكتب تهيئة الدعوى أو الطعن</orig>) (stipulated in Article (45) bis) is not considered a judicial body, nor does it undertake any action that would prejudice the legal positions of the litigants. Rather, it plays a preparatory regulatory role aimed at raising the level of procedural readiness of the lawsuit or appeal before they are presented to the court, ensuring the effective utilization of the period prior to the first session, thereby preventing the delay of the lawsuit due to trivial formalities or the readiness of the litigants, and thus enhancing the effectiveness of digital litigation based on speed and transparency, without prejudice to the guarantees established for the parties to the lawsuit.

This aims to regulate and tighten the litigant's right to recuse the judge hearing their case in a manner that ensures the achievement of its purpose and limits the abuse of its use, which practical experience has revealed. Accordingly, Article One of the draft also stipulated the replacement of the texts of Articles (106), (108), and (109) of the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> with other texts, and its Article Three added a new paragraph to the text of Article (107) of this law, and a new article to it numbered (109) bis, so that the draft decree-law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> includes several amendments to the existing law, which are as follows:

### First:
The guarantee <orig>الكفالة</orig> submitted by the applicant for recusal has become two hundred dinars. Furthermore, if the request for recusal is rejected, or the right to it is forfeited, or it is deemed inadmissible or void, the court shall rule – in addition to confiscating the guarantee stipulated in the existing law – to fine the applicant for recusal an amount not less than five hundred dinars and not exceeding one thousand dinars, provided that the fine multiplies with the number of judges requested to be recused.

### Second:
Prohibition of re-requesting the recusal of the same judge in the original lawsuit.

### Third:
To ensure the speedy resolution of pending recusal requests, the draft obligated the President of the Court <orig>رئيس المحكمة</orig> or their deputy to appoint the circuit responsible for hearing the recusal request and to set a date for its urgent consideration before it, and that the judgment on the recusal request be issued within a period not exceeding one month from the date set for its consideration before it.

### Fourth:
Amendment of the effect of submitting a recusal request regarding the original lawsuit, such that the submission of the first recusal request now results in the suspension of the original lawsuit. Accordingly, the submission of any other recusal request, whether by the first litigant requesting recusal or other litigants in the original lawsuit, will not result in its suspension unless the court hearing the other recusal request, and upon the request of one of the litigants, deems it appropriate to suspend the consideration of the original lawsuit.

### Fifth:
The draft addressed what practical experience revealed regarding the hypothetical submission of a request to recuse the court appointed by the President of the Court <orig>رئيس المحكمة</orig> to hear the recusal request. The draft deemed that this should not result in the suspension of the consideration of the request. To address the exigencies of the situation, the draft allowed the court appointed to hear the request for recusal of the court that was hearing the recusal request, and upon the request of one of the litigants, to order the suspension of proceedings on the recusal request whenever it deems it appropriate.

Given that the amounts of fines imposed by courts on litigants or penalties imposed by the Minister of Justice <orig>وزير العدل</orig> in accordance with the texts of Articles (53), (65)/second paragraph, (69) (first paragraph), (70) (first paragraph), (76), and (136) (second paragraph) of the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig> no longer achieve the purposes for which they were established, it became necessary to increase their value.

Furthermore, the current amounts of guarantees <orig>الكفالات</orig> under the current law, due to their small value, are no longer sufficient to ensure seriousness. Therefore, it was deemed appropriate to increase the amounts of guarantees stipulated in Articles (137) (second paragraph), (150) (second paragraph), (159) (third paragraph), (187) (third paragraph), and (211) (second paragraph) of the same law, which are the guarantees related to appeals <orig>الطعن بالاستئناف</orig> or petitions <orig>الالتماس</orig>, lawsuits filed by third parties objecting to judgments issued therein, the nullity of arbitral awards, and temporary injunctions <orig>الإشكالات الوقتية</orig>.

This is what Article Two of the present draft decree-law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> stipulated.

Article Three of the draft – among other provisions – included the addition of a new article to the aforementioned Civil and Commercial Procedures Law <orig>قانون المرافعات المدنية والتجارية</orig>, numbered (43) bis, which stipulates that (the value of compensation claims resulting from civil liability filed against an air carrier shall be estimated at their value in Special Drawing Rights <orig>وحدات حقوق السحب الخاصة</orig> units, equivalent in Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>الدينار الكويتي</orig> according to the valuation adopted by the International Monetary Fund <orig>صندوق النقد الدولي</orig> on the day the lawsuit is filed. Any change in the value of the units occurring after the lawsuit is filed shall not be included in this estimation).

Article Four of the presented draft decree-law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> obligated the Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – to implement this decree-law, provided that it shall be effective from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Decree-Law No. 134 of 2025
## Issuing the Law Regulating the Use and Protection of the Red Crescent and Red Cross Emblems

- After reviewing the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhul-Qa'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to May 10, 2024 AD,
- And the Penal Code <orig>قانون الجزاء</orig> issued by Law No. (16) of 1960, and its amending laws,
- And the Code of Criminal Procedure and Trials <orig>قانون الإجراءات والمحاكمات الجزائية</orig> issued by Law No. (17) of 1960, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (4) of 1962 regarding Patents, Industrial Designs and Models, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (24) of 1962 regarding Clubs and Public Benefit Associations, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (24) of 1963 establishing the Supreme Defense Council <orig>مجلس الدفاع الأعلى</orig>, amended by Decree-Law No. (53) of 1987,
- And Decree-Law No. (15) of 1992 approving the Headquarters Agreement between the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the International Committee of the Red Cross <orig>اللجنة الدولية للصليب الأحمر</orig>,
- And Law No. (28) of 1996 regarding the Regulation of the Pharmacy Profession and Circulation of Medicines, amended by Law No. (30) of 2016,
- And the Patent Law (System) <orig>نظام براءات الاختراع</orig> for the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> States issued by Law No. (71) of 2013,
- And the Trademark Law (System) <orig>نظام العلامات التجارية</orig> for the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> States issued by Law No. (13) of 2015,
- And Law No. (75) of 2019 regarding Copyright and Related Rights,
- And Law No. (70) of 2020 regarding the Practice of Medicine and Allied Professions, Patients' Rights, and Health Facilities,
- And the Decree issued on August 12, 1967, approving the accession of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to the Geneva Conventions signed on August 12, 1949, concerning the Amelioration of the Condition of Wounded, Sick and Shipwrecked Members of Armed Forces at Sea, the Amelioration of the Condition of Wounded and Sick Members of Armed Forces in the Field, the Treatment of Prisoners of War, and the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War,
- And the Decree issued on December 3, 1984, approving the accession of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> to the two Additional Protocols to the Geneva Conventions of August 12, 1949, concerning the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts and the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:

### Article One
The provisions of the attached Law regarding the regulation of the use and protection of the Red Crescent and Red Cross emblems shall be enforced.

### Article Two
The Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig> shall issue the executive regulations for the attached Law, based on the submission of the Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig>, within six months from the date of publication of this Decree-Law in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

### Article Three
Civilian medical units belonging to the private sector, as stipulated in the attached Law, whose activities at the time of issuance of this Decree-Law show aspects inconsistent with the provisions of the attached Law, must regularize their status by removing the violating aspects within six months from the date of entry into force of the provisions of this Decree-Law.

### Article Four
The Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective competencies – shall implement this Decree-Law, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Law Regulating the Use and Protection of the Red Crescent and Red Cross Emblems

## Article (1)
### Definitions
For the purpose of applying the provisions of this Law, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings assigned to each of them:
1.

1.  **The State**: The State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>.
2.  **National Society**: The Kuwait Red Crescent Society <orig>جمعية الهلال الأحمر الكويتي</orig>, officially authorized by the State to carry out voluntary humanitarian relief work in times of peace and war, and uses one of the internationally recognized emblems.
3.  **Military Medical Units**: Medical facilities that provide health services to the armed forces, their medical officers and personnel, and their transport vehicles.
4.  **Civilian Medical Units**: Civilian health bodies, institutions, and facilities affiliated with the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig>, or the private sector licensed to provide healthcare in the State, and their transport vehicles, and their medical personnel, including practitioners of medicine and allied professions.
5.  **The Emblem**: The Red Crescent emblem and the Red Cross emblem, and their equivalents among the internationally recognized emblems based on international agreements to which the State is a party, and for which a decision is issued by the Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig>.
6.  **Red Crescent Emblem**: A drawing consisting of a red crescent on a white background, facing the viewer's right and the wearer's left, internationally recognized in accordance with the Geneva Conventions of 1949 and their Additional Protocols, as shown in the table attached to this Law.
7.  **Red Cross Emblem**: A drawing consisting of a plus sign (a mathematical symbol composed of two straight lines intersecting perpendicularly, with one dividing the other into two equal halves) in red on a white background, internationally recognized in accordance with the Geneva Conventions of 1949 and their Additional Protocols, as shown in the table attached to this Law.
8.  **Armband**: A mark placed on the left arm of the protected person, bearing the emblem.
9.  **Identity Card**: A document containing the bearer's surname, full name, date of birth, personal photograph, rank, and other essential data of the bearer, prepared in accordance with the model annexed to the First Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded and Sick in Armed Forces in the Field, signed in 1949.
10. **Executive Regulations**: The executive regulations of this Law.

## Article (2)
### Categories Authorized to Use the Emblems
It is prohibited – whether in peacetime or during international and non-international armed conflicts – to use the emblem for categories other than the following:
1.  Military Medical Units.
2.  Civilian Medical Units affiliated with the State that use the emblem as part of their official insignia, without prejudice to the provisions of this Law, as regulated by the Executive Regulations.
3.  Civilian Medical Units affiliated with the private sector that are licensed to use the emblem by the competent authority. The Executive Regulations shall specify this authority, and the conditions, rules, and controls related to this license.
4.  Personnel affiliated with the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig> and its units, facilities, and transport vehicles, in accordance with the regulations issued by a decision of the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig>, provided that its name is written on the Red Crescent emblem.
5.  Anyone authorized to use the emblem in accordance with the provisions of this Law and the Executive Regulations.

## Article (3)
### Use of the Red Crescent Emblem for the Protection of Military Medical Units
The Red Crescent emblem shall be used for the purpose of protecting Military Medical Units under the supervision of the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig> in accordance with the provisions of this Law and the rules for the use of emblems stipulated in the Geneva Conventions of 1949 and their Additional Protocols.
Officers and personnel of Military Medical Units must carry armbands and identity cards issued to them by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>.
The Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig> may authorize army officers and personnel not referred to in the preceding paragraph, and police force and National Guard <orig>الحرس الوطني</orig> officers and personnel, who are trained to act as nurses or auxiliary stretcher-bearers for the wounded or sick when needed, to wear armbands bearing the Red Crescent emblem in miniature dimensions approved by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>, provided that their military identity documents prove the type of special training they received, the temporary nature of their duties, and their right to wear the armband.

## Article (4)
### Use of the Red Crescent Emblem by the National Society and State-Affiliated Civilian Medical Units
The National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig> shall use the Red Crescent emblem for indicative purposes, through its affiliated personnel, units, facilities, and transport vehicles, for the purpose of distinction, provided that the name of the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig> is written on the emblem. The National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig> shall regulate this use as specified by the Executive Regulations.

Civilian medical units affiliated with the State may use the Red Crescent emblem as part of their official logos, for identification purposes, provided it does not conflict with the provisions of this Law and its Executive Regulations.

### Article (5)
Use of the Emblem by Civilian Medical Units in Times of Armed Conflict
In times of armed conflict, the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig> may place civilian medical units at the disposal of the army. These units may be authorized to use the emblem by the Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig> after notifying the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig>. In this case, military laws, orders, and instructions shall apply to them.
The authorization issued for the use of the emblem, and the conditions and rules for its use, shall all be determined in the manner specified by the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig>.

### Article (6)
Use of the Emblem by the International Committee and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
The International Committee of the Red Cross <orig>اللجنة الدولية للصليب الأحمر</orig>, and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies <orig>الاتحاد الدولي لجمعيات الصليب الأحمر والهلال الأحمر</orig> or any of its affiliated societies may use the emblem in various activities they undertake in the State after obtaining a license from the competent authorities, in the manner specified by the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig>.

### Article (7)
Controls and Standards for the Use of the Emblem, Armband, and Identity Cards
The Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> shall specify the controls and standards for the use of the emblem and the armband, taking into account the following provisions:
1- The emblem shall be large and clearly visible when placed on medical units, facilities, and means of transport, or for distinguishing objects related to a Red Crescent or Red Cross institution in times of armed conflict. The name of the using entity shall be registered on these emblems.
2- Armbands shall be used in miniature dimensions.
3- Identity cards issued by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig> to the categories mentioned in Article (3) of this Law shall bear the Red Crescent emblem or the Red Cross emblem.
Authorization may be granted for the use of identity cards to distinguish persons associated with a Red Crescent or Red Cross institution, provided that the entities to which these persons belong are registered with these cards.

### Article (8)
Prohibition of Using the Emblem in Association Names, Trademarks, and Patents
It is prohibited to publicize associations, register trade names, or deposit industrial and commercial marks, designs, industrial models, and patents that use the emblem stipulated in this Law, or any name, emblem, or mark that causes confusion or similarity with any of them.

### Article (9)
Crimes and Penalties
Without prejudice to any more severe penalty stipulated in any other law, anyone who uses the emblem or its name, whether original or counterfeit, and regardless of the purpose of such use, in circumstances other than those stipulated in this Law, shall be punished by imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year, and by a fine of not less than five hundred Dinars <orig>دينار</orig> and not exceeding five thousand Dinars <orig>دينار</orig>, or by one of these two penalties.
Anyone who commits any of the following acts shall be punished by imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year, and by a fine of not less than one thousand Dinars <orig>دينار</orig> and not exceeding ten thousand Dinars <orig>دينار</orig>, or by one of these two penalties:
1- Placing the emblem or its name on shops, stickers, advertisements, promotional leaflets, trade papers, goods, or packaging, or selling, promoting, or displaying goods bearing the emblem or its name.
2- Intentionally damaging the emblem or rendering it unfit for use for purposes other than those for which it is intended.
3- Intentionally misusing the emblem or its name or anything equivalent thereto, or counterfeiting it.
The penalty shall be imprisonment for a period of not less than one year and not exceeding three years, and a fine not exceeding ten thousand Dinars <orig>دينار</orig>, or one of these two penalties, if the crime is committed in times of armed conflict.
Without prejudice to the rights of bona fide third parties, the court shall in all cases order the removal of the violation at the expense of the offender, and the confiscation or destruction of seized items or any tools used in the commission of such crimes.

### Article (10)
Without prejudice to any more severe penalty stipulated in any other law, anyone who uses or orders the use of the emblem or its name in times of armed conflict treacherously to achieve military gains by leading others to believe that the scope of protection afforded to these emblems is realized, and this results in severe harm to others or their physical safety, shall be punished by imprisonment for a period of not less than three years and not exceeding seven years.
If these acts result in the death of one or more persons, the penalty shall be death or life imprisonment.

### Article (11)
The penalty shall be doubled in all cases of recidivism in committing any of the crimes stipulated in this Law.

### Article (12)
Concluding Provisions
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> alone shall be competent to investigate, dispose of, and prosecute the crimes stipulated in this Law.

### Article (13)
The Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> shall specify all controls, rules, and procedures necessary for the implementation of the provisions of this Law.

</table># Explanatory Memorandum
## for Decree-Law No. 134 of 2025
Issuing the Law Regulating the Use and Protection of
the Red Crescent and Red Cross Emblems

Since the conclusion of the 1929 Geneva Conventions, signatory states have been obligated to enact legislation to protect the humanitarian emblems stipulated in these two conventions, namely the Red Cross, Red Crescent, and Red Lion and Sun emblems.
<page_end>24</page_end>

This obligation was confirmed in the four Geneva Conventions of 1949, considering that these emblems are fundamental for distinguishing and protecting the wounded, sick, and medical personnel, as well as medical facilities and means of transport.
Accordingly, the First Geneva Convention of 1949 <orig>اتفاقية جنيف الأولى لعام 1949</orig> for the Amelioration of the Condition of the Wounded and Sick in Armed Forces in the Field included the provisions of Chapter VII, titled "The Distinctive Emblem," and these provisions covered the emblem in Articles (38) to (44). It also included provisions for the protection of emblems in Article (53) and explicitly stipulated in Article (54) the obligation of the parties to the Geneva Conventions <orig>اتفاقيات جنيف</orig> to enact the necessary legislation to prevent and suppress abuses.
The same applies to the Second Geneva Convention of 1949 <orig>اتفاقية جنيف الثانية لعام 1949</orig> for the Amelioration of the Condition of Wounded, Sick and Shipwrecked Members of Armed Forces at Sea, where Chapter VI was dedicated to the protection of the distinctive emblem, and this was mentioned in Articles (41) to (45), with Article (45) stipulating the obligation of the High Contracting Parties to issue special legislation to prevent and suppress the misuse of the emblem.
Similarly, regarding the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 <orig>اتفاقية جنيف الرابعة لعام 1949</orig> relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War, it clarified in Articles (18) to (22) the necessity of distinguishing civilian hospitals, aircraft, trains, convoys, and medical ships whose use is restricted to transporting wounded and sick civilians.
Upon the conclusion of Additional Protocol I of 1977 <orig>البروتوكول الإضافي الأول لعام 1977</orig> to the Geneva Conventions of 1949, the emblem was defined in Article (8) thereof, and Article (9) clarified its scope of application. Articles (37, 38, and 39) regulated the provisions for the protection of the emblem, and Article (37) paragraph (d) included the crime of perfidy using humanitarian emblems.
Finally, Article (12) of Additional Protocol II of 1977 <orig>البروتوكول الثاني لعام 1977</orig> to the Geneva Conventions of 1949 included provisions for the protection of the distinctive emblem. Given the ratification by states of the four Geneva Conventions of 1949 and the two Additional Protocols of 1977, and to fulfill the contractual obligations incumbent upon states, it is necessary to enact special legislation to protect the emblems of the Red Cross <orig>الصليب الأحمر</orig> and the Red Crescent <orig>الهلال الأحمر</orig>.
Therefore, all states are obligated, in accordance with the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties <orig>قانون فيينا للمعاهدات الدولية</orig>, to implement their contractual obligations in good faith; this necessitates the enactment of appropriate legislation by each state to protect the emblems of the Red Crescent <orig>الهلال الأحمر</orig> and the Red Cross <orig>الصليب الأحمر</orig>.
Since the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> acceded to the four Geneva Conventions of 1949 on 2/9/1967 and to the two Additional Protocols to the Geneva Conventions of 1977 on 17/1/1985, it becomes clear that the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> is obligated, by virtue of its accession to these instruments, to take the necessary legislative measures to prevent the misuse of the Red Crescent <orig>الهلال الأحمر</orig> and Red Cross <orig>الصليب الأحمر</orig> emblems. And since the Amiri Decree <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024, and Article (4) thereof stipulated that laws shall be issued by decree-laws, the present draft decree-law <orig>مشروع المرسوم بقانون الماثل</orig> was prepared, which included four articles. The first article stipulated that the provisions of the accompanying law regarding the use and protection of the Red Crescent <orig>الهلال الأحمر</orig> and Red Cross <orig>الصليب الأحمر</orig> emblems shall be implemented.
Its second article stipulated that the executive regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> for the accompanying law shall be issued by the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig> based on a proposal from the Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig> within six months from the date of publication of this decree-law in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.
Its third article obligated private sector civilian medical units <orig>الوحدات الطبية المدنية التابعة للقطاع الخاص</orig> stipulated in the accompanying law at the time of its issuance to regularize their status in accordance with the provisions of the accompanying law within six months from the date of entry into force of the provisions of this decree-law.
Its fourth article also obligated the Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> and the Ministers – each within their respective competencies – to implement its provisions, provided that it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.
The provisions of the accompanying draft law <orig>مشروع القانون المرافق</orig> came in (13) articles. Article (1) clarified the meaning of the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig> as the Kuwait Red Crescent Society <orig>جمعية الهلال الأحمر الكويتي</orig>. It also clarified the concept of the emblem, the Red Crescent emblem <orig>شارة الهلال الأحمر</orig>, the Red Cross emblem <orig>شارة الصليب الأحمر</orig>, the armlet <orig>علامة الذراع</orig>, the identity card <orig>بطاقة تحقيق الهوية</orig>, and other definitions for terms contained in the law.
Article (2) specified the categories entitled to use the emblems stipulated in the accompanying draft law, whether in peacetime or armed conflicts. These are military medical units <orig>الوحدات الطبية العسكرية</orig>, state-affiliated civilian medical units <orig>الوحدات الطبية المدنية التابعة للدولة</orig>, private sector civilian medical units <orig>الوحدات الطبية المدنية التابعة للقطاع الخاص</orig>, individuals affiliated with the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig>, its facilities, and its units and means of transport, as well as

While Article (7) of the accompanying draft law and its executive regulations referred to the statement of controls and standards for the use of the emblem, armbands, and identity cards used by the categories mentioned in Article (3) of the accompanying draft law, taking into account the special provisions stipulated in this article for the size of the emblem, armband, and identity cards, in accordance with the Geneva Conventions of 1949 and their First Additional Protocol in this regard.
Article (8) of the accompanying draft law prohibited the declaration of associations, the registration of trade names, and the deposit of industrial and commercial marks, industrial designs and models, and patents that use any of the emblems stipulated in this draft, or their name, or any name, emblem, or mark that causes confusion or similarity with any of them.
Article (9) criminalized the intentional use of the emblems or any type of accompanying branches as an advertisement title or on posters, advertisements, promotional leaflets, commercial papers, goods, or packaging, or offering them for sale, selling them, or promoting goods distinguished by them. This article also prohibited their intentional destruction or rendering them unfit for use for purposes other than their designated purpose, and criminalized their misuse or imitation. It mandated the removal of the violation at the expense of the violator, and also permitted the confiscation or destruction of seized items or any tools used in the commission of any of those crimes, while respecting the rights of bona fide third parties.
Article (10) criminalized resorting to perfidy in using or ordering the use of one of the emblems or marks stipulated in the accompanying draft law or any tools used in committing any [act] based on the belief that the scope of protection guaranteed for these emblems or marks has been achieved to gain military advantages. It intensified the penalty in case of death resulting therefrom, punishing it with execution or life imprisonment.
Article (11) of the accompanying draft law stipulated the intensification of the penalty in case of recidivism in committing any of the crimes stipulated therein, where it decided to double the penalty in all cases if the offender returned to committing the same crime or any other crime covered by the accompanying draft law.
Article (12) restricted the jurisdiction for investigation, disposition, and prosecution of crimes contained in the accompanying draft law to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> exclusively.
Article (13) stipulated that the executive regulations shall specify the necessary controls, procedures, and provisions for implementing the provisions of the accompanying draft law.

Government health institutions and facilities affiliated with the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig> that use the emblem as part of their official logo for indicative purposes, in addition to private civilian medical or health establishments authorized to use the emblem by the competent authority, in accordance with the regulations issued by a decision or decisions from the Society itself, and those authorized to use the Red Crescent emblem or the Red Cross emblem in accordance with the provisions of the accompanying draft law and its executive regulations.
Article (3) of the accompanying draft law clarified the cases of using the Red Crescent emblem by military medical units for protection purposes, where it mandated military medical service personnel to carry armbands and identity cards bearing the Red Crescent emblem, granted to them by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>.
This article also permitted the Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig> to authorize army officers and personnel who are not members of military medical units, and leaders and personnel of the police force and National Guard <orig>الحرس الوطني</orig> who are specially trained to work when needed as nurses or assistant stretcher-bearers for the wounded or sick, to wear armbands bearing the Red Crescent emblem in miniature dimensions approved by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>. The military identity documents for each of them shall prove the type of special training they received, the temporary nature of their duties, and their right to wear the armband.
Article (4) specified that the use of the Red Crescent emblem by the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig> is for indicative purposes and with the intent of distinction, provided that its name is written on the emblem. This article granted the Society the right to regulate this use. It also permitted government health authorities, the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig> and its health facilities, to use the Red Crescent emblem within their official logos to indicate medical and ambulance services, and referred to the executive regulations of the accompanying draft law for clarification.
Article (5) of the accompanying draft law permitted the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig>, during armed conflicts, to place civilian medical units at the disposal of the army, with a license from the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig> for the use of the emblem for protection purposes during armed conflicts, with the obligation to notify the National Society <orig>الجمعية الوطنية</orig>. It also clarified the applicability of military laws, orders, and instructions to them, provided that the license for using the emblem, its conditions, and rules of use are specified as regulated by the executive regulations of the accompanying draft law.
Article (6) of the draft permitted the International Committee of the Red Cross <orig>اللجنة الدولية للصليب الأحمر</orig> and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies <orig>الاتحاد الدولي لجمعيات الصليب الأحمر والهلال الأحمر</orig> or any of the societies affiliated with the aforementioned Federation to use their respective emblems in various activities carried out by any of them in the State of

## Article Two
The ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law, which shall come into effect from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

Amir of Kuwait
**Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>**

Prime Minister
**Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>**

Minister of Foreign Affairs
**Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبد الله علي عبد الله اليحيا</orig>**

Issued at Seif Palace on: 9 Rabi' al-Awwal 1447 AH
Corresponding to: 1 September 2025 AD

The authorized capital of the Corporation is (100,000,000) one hundred million Islamic Dinars, divided into (100,000) one hundred thousand shares, with a par value of (1000) one thousand Islamic Dinars per share.
Whereas the Corporation aims to serve Islamic countries amidst the risks and instability surrounding the global economy, which generates an urgent need to facilitate credit and the flow of investments.
And given the exhaustion of the Corporation's subscription capacity, the Board of Governors of the Islamic Corporation for the Insurance of Investment and Export Credit <orig>المؤسسة الإسلامية لتأمين الاستثمار وائتمان الصادرات</orig> decided at its meeting held in Sharm El Sheikh, Arab Republic of Egypt, on June 4, 2022, to increase the Corporation's capital by an amount of (600,000,000) six hundred million Islamic Dinars for subscription by all current member states, each according to its shareholding percentage in the Corporation's capital before the approval of the increase.
The State of Kuwait's share of the increase amounts to (10,104) shares, valued at (10,104,000) Islamic Dinars, bringing the total contribution of the State of Kuwait to (17,604) shares with a total value of (17,604,000) Islamic Dinars.
And since this increase serves the interest of the State of Kuwait by enhancing its role in serving the Islamic system and increasing its good reputation in international forums, which prompted the competent authority (Ministry of Finance <orig>وزارة المالية</orig>) to request approval for this capital increase of the Corporation.
And whereas the approval of this increase entails financial obligations for the State, represented by the value of the shares that the State of Kuwait will subscribe to in the Corporation's capital, and it also included an amendment to existing laws.
To achieve this purpose, and based on the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD, the accompanying draft Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> has been prepared after the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig> approved the subscription to the capital increase of the Islamic Corporation for the Insurance of Investment and Export Credit <orig>المؤسسة الإسلامية لتأمين الاستثمار وائتمان الصادرات</orig> and authorized the government to take the subscription amount from the State's General Reserve <orig>الاحتياطي العام للدولة</orig>. The ministers shall implement this Decree-Law, and it shall come into effect from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.
<page_end>28</page_end>

# Explanatory Memorandum

Regarding Law by Decree No. 136 of 2025 <orig>المرسوم بقانون رقم 136 لسنة 2025</orig>
Approving a Memorandum of Understanding in the Field of
Cooperation and Exchange of Intelligence Information
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
And the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>

Desiring to encourage military cooperation between the two countries and to protect international peace and security, and wishing to enhance joint bilateral cooperation in the fields of security and military intelligence related to the two countries.

Therefore, on 15/1/2025, a Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة تفاهم</orig> in the field of cooperation and exchange of intelligence information was signed between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>.

Article (1) of the Memorandum addressed the primary purpose, Article (2) clarified the permissible areas of cooperation, Article (3) discussed the responsibilities of both the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig> and the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, Article (4) referred to the means of information exchange between the two parties, Article (5) stipulated the commitment of both parties to the confidentiality of the information they obtain, Article (6) referred to meetings for information exchange between specialists from both parties, Article (7) clarified that any dispute arising regarding the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum shall be settled between the two parties through consultations, and finally, Article (8) addressed the entry into force, amendment, renewal, and termination of the Memorandum.

Since this Memorandum serves the interest of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and does not conflict with its obligations in the Arab and international spheres.

And since the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig>, as the competent authority, has requested the preparation of the necessary legal instrument for ratification.

And since this Memorandum is considered among the agreements mentioned in the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, its approval shall therefore be by law in accordance with the provision of this paragraph.

And since the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024, and Article (4) thereof stipulated that laws shall be issued by decrees having the force of law <orig>مراسيم بقوانين</orig>, therefore, the draft Law by Decree <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> approving it, along with its explanatory memorandum, has been prepared.

Article One thereof stipulated the approval of the aforementioned Memorandum of Understanding <orig>مذكرة التفاهم</orig>, and Article Two thereof obligated the ministers, each within their respective competencies, to implement this Law by Decree <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig>, and that it shall be effective from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.
<page_end>29</page_end>

# Memorandum of Understanding in the Field of Cooperation and Exchange of
# Intelligence Information Between
## The Government of the State of Kuwait
## And the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia

For Kuwait
Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> - Legal Department <orig>الإدارة القانونية</orig>
Certified True Copy of the Memorandum of Understanding in the Field of Cooperation and Exchange of Intelligence Information Between
The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia

The Government of the State of Kuwait (represented by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>) and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia (represented by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>), hereinafter referred to as (the Parties), recognizing the necessity of encouraging military cooperation between the two countries and protecting international peace and security, and desiring to enhance joint security cooperation in the fields of military security and intelligence related to the two countries, in accordance with relevant national laws and regulations, and in line with the directives issued by them, have agreed as follows:

### Article One
### Purpose

The purpose of this Memorandum is to facilitate the exchange of military intelligence information authorized for disclosure based on the information disclosure policies followed by the Parties regarding matters of common interest related to threats to common interests, and to build and exchange advice on the means to achieve common military intelligence objectives, provided that the use of intelligence information exchanged between the Parties shall be limited to defensive purposes.
<page_end>30</page_end>

### Article Two
### Areas of Cooperation

1- Military activities of all types in countries agreed upon by both parties, provided that this includes the following:
a- Exchange of intelligence information from countries of common interest between both parties.
b- Monitoring situational developments and providing warning of any hostile intent or indicator towards both countries.
c- Land, sea, and air military activities in the Arabian Gulf region.
d- Any urgent threat to either party arising during a specific crisis.

2- Cooperation in combating global and regional terrorist activity affecting (the armed forces in both countries), including information on (targets, trends, organization, armament, movements, activities, and biographies of terrorist figures).
3- Cooperation in the field of signal intelligence, electronic warfare, and psychological warfare, as needed.
4- Cooperation in the field of aerial imagery (satellite images) for strategic targets in countries agreed upon by both parties.
5- Cooperation in the field of training, in areas required by both parties within their respective competencies.
6- Cooperation in the field of environmental intelligence.
7- Cooperation in the field of acquiring modern intelligence systems and technologies.

### Article Three
## Responsibilities
1- Kingdom of Saudi Arabia: The Director General of the General Directorate of Intelligence Policies <orig>المدير العام للإدارة العامة لسياسات الاستخبارات</orig> shall be the representative of the Saudi Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع السعودية</orig> in this Memorandum, and shall be responsible for formulating the policy guiding all activities of the Saudi Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع السعودية</orig> for the implementation of this Memorandum and monitoring its progress. The Head of the Armed Forces Intelligence Authority <orig>رئيس هيئة استخبارات القوات المسلحة</orig> shall be the executive responsible for this Memorandum, and the Saudi Military Attaché <orig>الملحق العسكري السعودي</orig> in Kuwait shall be the sole point of contact for the implementation of this Memorandum.
2- State of Kuwait: The Assistant Chief of Staff for Kuwaiti Intelligence and Security Authority <orig>معاون رئيس الأركان العامة لهيئة الاستخبارات والأمن الكويتي</orig> shall be the representative of the Kuwaiti Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع الكويتية</orig> in this Memorandum, and shall be responsible for formulating the policy guiding all activities of the Kuwaiti Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع الكويتية</orig> for the implementation of this Memorandum and monitoring its progress. The Director of Kuwaiti Intelligence <orig>مدير الاستخبارات الكويتية</orig> shall be the executive responsible for this Memorandum, and the Kuwaiti Military Attaché <orig>الملحق العسكري الكويتي</orig> at the Kuwaiti Embassy in the Kingdom shall be the sole point of contact for the implementation of this Memorandum.

### Article Five
#### Confidentiality of Information
Both parties shall ensure the confidentiality of this Memorandum through the following:
1.  Classifying this Memorandum of Understanding as (Top Secret).
2.  Each party agrees to grant intelligence information exchanged under this Memorandum the level of security protection provided by the originating state.
3.  Neither party shall be entitled to provide classified military information supplied by the other party – in accordance with this Memorandum – to a third party or an entity affiliated with or under the control of that party without obtaining written consent from the party that provided such information.
4.  Each party must ensure that persons authorized to access the information stipulated in this Memorandum have security clearances granted by their government at a level equivalent to – or commensurate with – the classification given to classified military information, and that their official duties require access to such information.
5.  Each party shall immediately notify the other party of the loss or suspected loss of any classified military information exchanged under this Memorandum, or if it is compromised.

### Article Six
## Information Exchange Meetings
1- Information exchange meetings shall be held between specialists from both Parties whenever necessary.
2- The two Parties shall inform each other of the topics to be discussed at the meeting (eight) weeks prior to its scheduled date.
3- The host Party shall prepare the work program and deliver it to the guest Party (thirty) days prior to the arrival date of its delegation.
4- The guest Party shall inform the host Party of the delegation's composition and the names of its participants (three) weeks prior to the meeting date.
5- The two Parties shall agree on accommodation and transportation expenses.
6- The two Parties shall coordinate in advance to determine the number of participants in the coordination meetings.

**Dispute Resolution**

### Article Eight
**Entry into Force, Termination, and Amendment of the Memorandum**

1- This Memorandum shall enter into force on the date of the last mutual notification between the Parties through diplomatic channels, confirming the completion of the necessary internal procedures for its entry into force.
2- The duration of this Memorandum shall be (five) years, renewable automatically unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate or not renew it at least (six) months prior to the specified date for its termination or non-renewal.
3- This Memorandum may be amended by agreement of the Parties, and such amendment shall be subject to the statutory procedures followed by each of them.

This Memorandum was signed in the city of Riyadh <orig>الرياض</orig> on 15 Rajab 1447 AH, corresponding to 8 January 2025 AD, in two original copies in the Arabic language.

## Explanatory Memorandum
## Regarding Decree-Law No. 137 of 2025
## Approving a Cooperation Agreement
## In the Field of Ports and Commercial Maritime Navigation
## Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the People's Republic of China
Desiring to strengthen friendly relations between the two countries and enhance cooperation between them in the field of maritime transport, develop commercial, scientific, and technical communication, exchange expertise, train personnel, and promote cooperation to ensure compliance with international agreements and guarantee navigation safety concerning vessels, crew members, passengers, and cargo, in addition to protecting the environment and improving the working environment and conditions for crew members, a cooperation agreement in the field of ports and commercial maritime navigation was signed between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the People's Republic of China in Kuwait City on 16/4/2025. This agreement consists of nineteen articles.

Article (1) provided definitions for the terms contained therein, Article (2) clarified its scope of application, and Article (3) addressed operational rights, including: enhancing cooperation and development in the field of commercial shipping between the two countries to facilitate the transport of goods and passengers. Article (4) also regulated how

Article (5) stipulated that the contracting parties must address smuggling crimes in accordance with applicable local laws and regulations. Article (6) emphasized the recognition by both contracting parties of the certificate of nationality and other ship-related documents issued by the competent authorities of the flag state.
Article (7) also stipulated the recognition by the contracting parties of identity documents issued by the competent authority of the other recognizing party for its crew members. Article (8) outlined the rights and obligations of crew members when stopping at ports belonging to the other recognizing party, in accordance with the laws and regulations in force therein.
Article (9) explained how crew members of both parties may depart, enter, and transit the territory of the other party. Article (10) also clarified that each party to the agreement has the right to establish consular shipping offices or commercial offices in the territory of both parties, and that the activities of these offices shall be in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in the host country.
Article (11) addressed criminal jurisdiction in the event of any crime occurring on board the vessels of one of the contracting parties.
Article (12) dealt with the situation where a vessel belonging to one of the contracting parties is exposed to danger or any other incident in the territorial sea or adjacent waters of the other recognizing party. In such a case, the crew members, the vessel, and its cargo must be granted the same protection afforded to its nationals, and rescue operations shall be consistent with international conventions on maritime search and rescue and relevant national legislation.
Article (13) also explained how to transfer profits and settle revenues of shipping companies belonging to one of the contracting parties in the territory of the other recognizing party, and mandated the exemption of such revenues from taxes.
Article (14) stipulated areas of cooperation, including: that cooperation between the contracting parties in the field of maritime transport shall be based on the principles of equality, recognition of national sovereignty, and mutual interest, as well as cooperation in various fields such as promoting commercial, scientific, and technical communication, exchanging expertise, and enhancing the development of maritime transport and ports for both contracting parties on the basis of equality and mutual interest.
Article (15) clarified that the conclusion of this Agreement does not affect the rights and obligations of either contracting party arising from its membership in any other international or regional organizations or treaties.
Article (16) also clarified that the vessels of both contracting parties must comply with the regulations related to the protection of the marine environment and the safety and security of maritime navigation in force in the ports of both contracting parties, and the provisions of international agreements and treaties to which both countries are parties.
Article (17) stipulated that in the event of any dispute arising from the interpretation or implementation of this Agreement, the parties shall endeavor to settle such dispute through friendly consultation and mutual understanding via diplomatic channels.
Article (18) addressed that representatives of the competent maritime authorities of both contracting parties may meet and discuss the implementation of this Agreement at a place and date agreed upon by the contracting parties.
Finally, Article (19) reviewed the final provisions regarding the entry into force of the Agreement, as well as how to activate and cancel it.
Given that this Agreement serves the interests of both states and does not conflict with the obligations of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> in the Arab and international spheres.
And since this Agreement is considered among the agreements mentioned in the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, its approval shall therefore be by law in accordance with the provision of this paragraph.
And since the Amiri Decree <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024 AD, and Article (4) thereof stipulated that laws shall be issued by decree-laws, therefore, the draft decree-law approving it, along with its explanatory memorandum, has been prepared.

# Agreement on Cooperation in the Field of Ports and Commercial Maritime Navigation

Between
The State of Kuwait
Ministry of Interior / Wizarat Al-Dakhiliya <orig>وزارة الداخلية</orig> - Legal Department
Certified True Copy
The Government of the People's Republic of China

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the People's Republic of China (hereinafter referred to as "the Contracting Parties"),
Desiring to strengthen the friendly relations between the two countries and to enhance cooperation between them in the field of maritime transport,
Based on the principles of equality and mutual benefit, freedom of navigation, and non-discrimination, have agreed as follows:

## Article 1
### Definitions

For the purposes of this Agreement:
1.  The term "Recognizing Party" or "Other Recognizing Party" means the Government of the People's Republic of China or the Government of the State of Kuwait.
2.  The term "Competent Maritime Authority" means:
    a) For the People's Republic of China: The Ministry of Transport of the People's Republic of China.
    b) For the State of Kuwait: The General Department of Coast Guard / Al-Idara Al-Amma li-Khafara Al-Sawahil <orig>الإدارة العامة لخفر السواحل</orig>, Ministry of Interior / Wizarat Al-Dakhiliya <orig>وزارة الداخلية</orig>.
3.  The term "Vessel" means any commercial vessel registered with the ship registration administration of one of the Contracting Parties in accordance with its national laws and flying the flag of that Party, including vessels owned or operated by a shipping company belonging to one of the Contracting Parties, but not flying the flag of a state acceptable to the Other Recognizing Party. However, the term "Vessel" does not include vessels used for non-commercial purposes such as warships, official boats, hydrographic survey vessels and other scientific research vessels, and fishing vessels.
4.  The term "Crew Member" means any person working or serving on board a vessel, whose name is included in the crew list and who holds the seafarer's identity documents referred to in Article 7 of this Agreement.
5.  The term "Shipping Company" means any company engaged in maritime transport using vessels it owns or operates, whose registered office is located in the territory of one of the Contracting Parties, which bears civil liabilities independently, and is recognized as a "shipping company" by the Recognizing Party in accordance with the national laws of the Recognizing Party.

6. The term "Port" refers to the waters surrounding the port in the territory of either of the Contracting Parties, which has been approved to be a center for international shipping.
7. The term "Bill of Lading (Manifest)" refers to the document that includes a comprehensive description of goods transported by vessels.

### Article 2
#### Scope
1. This Agreement does not apply to ports open to foreign vessels, coastal transport, and inland waterway transport, as well as activities reserved by any Contracting Party for its national organizations in accordance with its national laws, such as towing, pilotage, rescue operations, and port services in its maritime territory and inland waters.
2. If vessels of one Contracting Party sail from a port of the Recognizing Party to another port for loading goods from abroad or unloading goods from abroad, it shall not be considered coastal transport or inland waterway transport, unless these goods are loaded in one port and possibly unloaded in another port of the Recognizing Party, and also if these goods are coming from and to the other Contracting Party or from and to a third country. The same applies to the transport of passengers.

### Article 3
#### Operating Rights
1. The two Contracting Parties seek to promote cooperation and development in the field of commercial shipping between their ports for the transport of goods and passengers.
2. Vessels of one Contracting Party shall have the right to sail between the international commercial ports of the other Recognizing Party that are open to foreign vessels, for the transport of goods and passengers between the two Contracting Parties or between any Contracting Party and a third country.
3. The provisions contained in paragraph 2 of this Article shall not affect the right of vessels belonging to a third country to participate in the transport of goods and passengers between the two Contracting Parties, provided that the commercial maritime activities concerned are carried out in accordance with the laws, regulations, practices, and policies in force in both Parties.

## Article 4
### Treatment of Vessels in Port
1.  The Contracting Parties shall, within the limits of their applicable laws and regulations, take appropriate measures to facilitate and expedite maritime transport in order to avoid unnecessary delays for vessels and to simplify and expedite customs procedures and other port charges, including those related to access to reception facilities for the disposal of water from vessels.
2.  Each Contracting Party shall grant the other recognized Party the same preferential treatment granted to vessels belonging to other states in its ports with regard to the collection of port tonnage dues. Tonnage dues and charges for services rendered shall be calculated with full transparency.
3.  The provisions of paragraph 1 of this Article shall not oblige any Contracting Party to extend exemptions from compulsory pilotage requirements to vessels of the other recognized Party.
4.  The management of the cargo manifest, the unloading and transfer of imported shipments, as well as the inspection of vessels by customs, shall be carried out in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations of both Contracting Parties.

## Article 5
### Provisions on Smuggling
The Contracting Parties shall address smuggling offenses in accordance with their applicable laws and regulations.

## Article 6
### Ship Documents
1.  Each Contracting Party shall recognize the certificate of nationality and other ship documents carried by vessels of the other Contracting Party and issued by the competent authorities of the flag state.
2.  Vessels belonging to one of the Parties carrying valid tonnage certificates issued in accordance with the International Convention on Tonnage Measurement of Ships, 1969, and accepted by the other Contracting Party, shall not be re-measured in the ports of the other Contracting Party. All fees and taxes associated with ship tonnage shall be calculated and collected in accordance with the aforementioned certificates.

The Contracting Parties shall recognize the identity documents issued by the competent authority of the other Contracting Party to its crew members, and these documents are as follows:
    *   a) In the case of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, "Kuwaiti Seafarer's Service Book accompanied by a valid travel document".
    *   b) In the case of the People's Republic of China <orig>جمهورية الصين الشعبية</orig>, "Seafarer's Passport of the People's Republic of China".
2. Identity documents held by crew members from a state and personnel on board a vessel of one of the Contracting Parties, issued by the competent authorities in that third state, shall be recognized as valid documents if such documents are sufficient as passports or passport substitutes in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in the other recognizing party.

# Article 8
## Shore Leave for Crew Members
1. The competent authorities of one of the Contracting Parties shall provide facilities for the crew of the other recognizing party for their stay (their stay in its ports) and in accordance with its national laws and regulations. Crew members must comply with the applicable laws, regulations, and rules, as well as health and quarantine provisions regarding entry or exit, and the policies for epidemic prevention and control of the first recognizing party.
2. During the stay of a vessel of one of the Contracting Parties in a port of the other recognizing party, crew members holding the identity documents referred to in Article 7 of this Agreement, or passports, or other international travel documents, may go ashore and stay in the port city (visa-free port in accordance with the Convention on Facilitation of International Maritime Traffic (London, 1965) and its amendments), and shall comply with the laws and regulations in force in the host country. It is stipulated that the master of the vessel must have submitted the crew list to the relevant port authorities in accordance with port regulations upon going ashore and returning to the vessel, and crew members must also be subject to the immigration regulations and customs procedures in force in the other recognizing party.
3. While a vessel of one of the Contracting Parties is in the territory of the other recognizing party, the shipowner or their representative has the right to contact or meet with crew members in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations in the other recognizing party.

The competent authorities in either of the Contracting Parties, in accordance with the Convention on Facilitation of International Maritime Traffic (London, 1965) <orig>اتفاقية تسهيل حركة المرور البحري الدولي (لندن، 1965)</orig> and its amendments, as well as the laws and regulations in force in the first Recognizing Party, must grant crew members admitted to a hospital in the territory of the first Recognizing Party the right to remain for the duration of their necessary treatment, then return to their home country by necessary means of transport or transfer to another port of the same Recognizing Party to board vessels.

## Article 9
### Departure, Entry, and Transit of Crew Members
1. Crew members from one of the Contracting Parties holding the identity documents specified in Article 7 of this Agreement and valid visas (attached to a passport or other international travel documents) are permitted to enter, depart, or transit the territory of the other Recognizing Party by any means of passenger transport for the purpose of boarding vessels, transit, repatriation, or any other reasons acceptable to the competent authorities of the other Recognizing Party. Visas and transit entry to one of the Contracting Parties must be issued to persons holding the identity documents mentioned in Article 7 as requested by the other Recognizing Party, even if they do not hold the nationality of the Recognizing Party.
2. Each Recognizing Party reserves the right to refuse entry to its territory to any crew member it deems undesirable, even if the crew member holds the identity documents specified in Article 7 of this Agreement.
3. The provisions of this Article shall not affect the applicable laws and regulations concerning the entry, stay, transit, or departure of foreigners from the territory of either of the Contracting Parties.

## Article 10
### Offices Outside the Territory
Shipping companies or affiliated institutions of each Recognizing Party have the right to establish shipping representative offices or commercial offices in the territory of the other Recognizing Party, in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in that Recognizing Party. The activities of these offices must be in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in the host country.

## Article 11
### Criminal Jurisdiction
1.  The provisions of Article 27 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea of 1982 shall apply in the event of any crime occurring on board vessels of one Contracting Party in the territorial seas of the other Recognizing Party.
2.  The provisions of paragraph 1 of this Article shall not affect the criminal jurisdiction exercised by either Contracting Party in accordance with its national laws and regulations.

## Article 12
### Salvage at Sea
1.  In the event that a vessel of one Contracting Party encounters danger or any other incident in the territorial sea or adjacent waters of the other Recognizing Party, the same salvage and assistance operations shall be provided to the crew members and passengers on board that vessel as if it were providing or receiving them, and the competent authorities of the first Recognizing Party shall be notified as soon as possible.
2.  Salvage operations and their organization must be consistent with international conventions on maritime search and rescue of 1979, as well as relevant national legislation in dealing with commercial salvage operations for the damaged vessel and goods and in dealing with maritime incidents. No discrimination shall be exercised regarding the fees related thereto.
3.  If goods, equipment, or materials unloaded or salvaged from the damaged vessel require temporary storage on the shore of the other Recognizing Party to be transported from there to the country of origin or to any third country, the competent authorities of the Recognizing Party shall provide facilities for these arrangements in accordance with its national laws and regulations. No taxes shall be imposed by the other Recognizing Party on these goods, equipment, or materials as long as they are not intended for sale or consumption within the territory of the Recognizing Party.
4.  The provisions of paragraph 3 of this Article shall not affect the application of the applicable laws and regulations of the Contracting Parties concerning temporary storage of goods.

### Article 13
**Transfer of Profits**

1.  The revenues of shipping companies belonging to one of the Contracting Parties, obtained in the territory of the other Contracting Party, may be settled in freely convertible currencies acceptable to both Contracting Parties. All revenues may also be used to pay expenses incurred in the territory of the other Contracting Party and/or freely transferred abroad at the exchange rate published by the Central Bank of the other Contracting Party on the date of transfer. Both Contracting Parties shall facilitate these transfers.
2.  The revenues of shipping companies belonging to one of the Contracting Parties, resulting from international shipping in the territory of the other Contracting Party, shall be exempt from taxes.

### Article 14
**Cooperation**

1.  Cooperation between the Contracting Parties in the field of maritime transport shall be based on the principles of equality, recognition of national sovereignty, and mutual interest.
2.  Both Contracting Parties shall authorize their competent authorities to take the necessary measures and hold the necessary consultative meetings for the implementation of this Agreement in accordance with national laws and regulations.
3.  Without prejudice to the obligations stipulated in international laws and regulations, the Contracting Parties agree to cooperate in the following areas, including but not limited to:
    a) Encouraging competent maritime authorities, maritime organizations, and companies to develop bilateral maritime cooperation;
    b) Promoting commercial, scientific, and technical communication, exchange of expertise, and training of personnel;
    c) Promoting the development of maritime transport and ports for both Contracting Parties on the basis of equality and mutual interest, and removing any obstacles that may hinder their development;
    d) Enhancing cooperation to ensure compliance with international agreements, and ensuring the safety of navigation with regard to vessels, crew members, passengers, and cargo, in addition to protecting the environment, and improving the working environment and conditions for crew members.

### Article 15
**Relations with Other Organizations and Treaties**
This Agreement shall not affect the rights and obligations of either Contracting Party arising from its membership in any other international or regional organizations or treaties.

### Article 16
**Environmental Protection, Safety and Security of Maritime Navigation**
Vessels of both Contracting Parties shall comply with the regulations pertaining to the protection of the marine environment, and the safety and security of maritime navigation in force in the ports of both Contracting Parties, and the provisions of international conventions and treaties to which both countries are parties.

### Article 17
**Settlement of Disputes**
In the event of any dispute between the Contracting Parties concerning the interpretation or implementation of this Agreement, the competent authorities of both Contracting Parties shall settle it through amicable consultation on the basis of mutual understanding. Should an agreement not be reached, it shall be settled through diplomatic channels.

### Article 18
**Consultation**
Upon the request of either Contracting Party, representatives of the competent maritime authorities of both Contracting Parties may meet to discuss the implementation of this Agreement and any other proposals put forward by either Party at a place and date agreed upon by both Contracting Parties.

### Article 19
**Entry into Force, Amendment and Termination of the Agreement**
1.  Each Contracting Party shall notify the other Contracting Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of the completion of its necessary national legal procedures for the entry into force of this Agreement. This Agreement shall enter into force sixty (60) days after the date of receipt of the last notification.
2.  This Agreement may be amended by the full consent of both Contracting Parties. The amendment shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph 1 of this Article. As an integral part of this Agreement, the amendment shall have the same validity as this Agreement.

1.  The term "the Contracting Party" or "the other Contracting Party" refers to the Government of the People's Republic of China or the Government of the State of Kuwait.
2.  The term "Maritime Competent Authority" refers to:
    i) in the case of the People's Republic of China, the Ministry of Transport of the People's Republic of China;
    ii) in the case of the State of Kuwait, (General Department of the Coast Guard), the Ministry of Interior.
3.  The term "Vessel" refers to any commercial vessel, which is registered in the ship registration administration of one Contracting Party in accordance with its national laws and flies its national flag, including vessels owned or operated by a shipping company of one Contracting Party but flying the flag of a third country acceptable to the other Contracting Party. The term "Vessel", however, shall not include vessels used for non-commercial purposes like warships, official boats, hydro-graphic and other scientific research vessels and fishing vessels.
4.  The term "crew member" refers to any person employed to workor serve on board a vessel, whose name is included in the crew list
and who is a holder of the seafarers' identity documents as referred to
in Article 7 of the present Agreement.
