### ARTICLE 5
### THE SMUGGLING PROVISION
The Contracting Parties should address the smuggling crimes in
accordance with the respective domestic laws and regulations.

### ARTICLE 6
### DOCUMENTS OF VESSELS
1. Each Contracting Party recognizes the nationality certificate and
other ship's documents held by vessels of the other Contracting
Party and issued by the competent authorities of the flag state.
2. Vessels of one Contracting Party holding valid tonnage certificates
issued in compliance with the International Convention on
Tonnage Measurement of Ships, 1969 and accepted by the other
Contracting Party shall not be re-measured in the ports of the other
Contracting Party. All dues and charges based on the tonnage of
the vessels shall be calculated and collected in accordance with the
above-mentioned certificates.

## ARTICLE 19
**ENTRY INTO FORCE, AMENDMENT AND TERMINATION**
1. Each Contracting Party shall notify the other Contracting Party
through diplomatic channels in writing of its completion of
national legal procedures as required for the entry into force of this
Agreement. This Agreement shall enter into force sixty (60) days
after the receipt of the last notification.
2. This Agreement may be amended with unanimity of the
Contracting Parties. The amendment shall enter into force in
accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph 1 of this
Article. As an inseparable part of this Agreement, the amendment
shall have the same validity of this Agreement.
3. This Agreement shall remain in force for three (3) years. This
Agreement shall be renewed automatically for successive periods
of three (3) years unless either of the Contracting Parties notifies
the other Contracting Party in writing for the termination of this
Agreement six (6) months prior to the expiration of this
Agreement.
4. Either Contracting Party may terminate this Agreement by written

Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1755, Seventy-First Year 64

</header>

The governments of the two states, after the commencement of the application of the aforementioned Agreement, deemed it necessary to amend some of its provisions, as practical application revealed the necessity of this amendment, which concluded in the following:
- In Article (1) of the Protocol, the Preamble of the Agreement was cancelled and replaced with the text contained in the same Article.
- In Article (2) of the amended Protocol, sub-paragraph (3) of Article (2) of the Agreement concerning "Taxes Covered" was cancelled and replaced with the text contained in the same Article.
- In Article (3), paragraph (1) of Article (25) of the Agreement concerning "Mutual Agreement Procedure <orig>إجراءات الاتفاق المتبادل</orig>" was cancelled and replaced with the text contained in the same Article.
- In Article (4), Article (26) of the Agreement concerning "Exchange of Information" was cancelled and replaced with the text contained in the same Article.
- Article (5), Article (29) of the Agreement concerning "Entitlement to Benefits" was cancelled and replaced with the text contained in the same Article.
- Finally, Article (6) of the amended Protocol specified the procedures for its ratification, the date of its entry into force, and the date of its applicability with respect to tax years beginning on or after January 1 of the calendar year following the entry into force of the Protocol.
Since the provisions of the Protocol serve the interest of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and do not conflict with its obligations in the Arab and international spheres, and the competent authority – the Ministry of Finance <orig>وزارة المالية</orig> – had submitted the Protocol and requested the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> to take ratification procedures, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> also requested its study and the preparation of the necessary legal instrument for its issuance.
Whereas the Protocol aims to amend the Agreement for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion <orig>اتفاقية تجنب الازدواج الضريبي ومنع التهرب المالي</orig> with respect to taxes on income and on capital, which was previously issued by Law No. 19 of 2010 <orig>القانون رقم 19 لسنة 2010</orig>, it is therefore necessary to ratify it by law in accordance with the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, and based on Article Four of the Amiri Decree <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 10/5/2024.
Accordingly, a draft Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig> approving the aforementioned Protocol and its explanatory memorandum have been prepared and attached in the appropriate legal form.

# Decree-Law No. 138 of 2025 <orig>مرسوم بقانون رقم 138 لسنة 2025</orig>
Approving the Protocol Amending the Agreement
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg <orig>دوقية لكسمبورغ الكبرى</orig>
for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion
with respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital

- Having reviewed the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>,
- And the Amiri Decree <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Law No. 19 of 2010 <orig>القانون رقم 19 لسنة 2010</orig> approving the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg <orig>دوقية لكسمبورغ الكبرى</orig> for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion <orig>تجنب الازدواج الضريبي ومنع التهرب المالي</orig> with respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزير الخارجية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig>:

## Article One
Approval of the Protocol Amending the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg <orig>دوقية لكسمبورغ الكبرى</orig> for the Avoidance of Double Taxation and the Prevention of Fiscal Evasion <orig>تجنب الازدواج الضريبي ومنع التهرب المالي</orig> with respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital, signed in Luxembourg on 12 Sha'ban 1442 AH, corresponding to 25 March 2021, the texts of which are attached to this Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig>.

## Article Two
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree-Law <orig>المرسوم بقانون</orig>, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# PROTOCOL
## AMENDMENT TO THE AGREEMENT
BETWEEN
THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE GRAND DUCHY OF LUXEMBOURG <orig>دوقية لكسمبورغ الكبرى</orig>
FOR THE AVOIDANCE OF DOUBLE TAXATION AND THE PREVENTION OF FISCAL EVASION WITH RESPECT TO
TAXES ON INCOME AND ON CAPITAL, SIGNED IN
LUXEMBOURG ON DECEMBER 11, 2007

THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE GRAND DUCHY OF LUXEMBOURG <orig>دوقية لكسمبورغ الكبرى</orig>,
DESIRING TO CONCLUDE A PROTOCOL TO AMEND THE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF
KUWAIT <orig>الكويت</orig> AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE GRAND DUCHY OF LUXEMBOURG <orig>دوقية لكسمبورغ الكبرى</orig> FOR THE AVOIDANCE OF DOUBLE TAXATION AND THE PREVENTION OF FISCAL
EVASION WITH RESPECT TO TAXES ON INCOME AND ON CAPITAL, SIGNED IN LUXEMBOURG
ON DECEMBER 11, 2007 (HEREINAFTER REFERRED TO AS "THE AGREEMENT").

HAVE AGREED AS FOLLOWS:

State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
Ministry of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزارة الخارجية</orig> - Legal Department <orig>الإدارة القانونية</orig>
Certified True Copy -2-
### ARTICLE 1
THE PREAMBLE OF THE AGREEMENT SHALL BE DELETED AND REPLACED BY THE FOLLOWING:
THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE GRAND DUCHY OF LUXEMBOURG <orig>دوقية لكسمبورغ الكبرى</orig>,
DESIRING TO FURTHER DEVELOP THEIR ECONOMIC RELATIONS AND TO ENHANCE COOPERATION
IN TAX MATTERS, ARE COMMITTED TO CONCLUDING AN AGREEMENT FOR THE PREVENTION OF DOUBLE TAXATION WITH RESPECT TO
THE TAXES COVERED ON INCOME AND CAPITAL WITHOUT CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR NON-TAXATION
OR REDUCED TAXATION THROUGH TAX EVASION OR AVOIDANCE (INCLUDING THROUGH

## Article 5
Article 29 of the Agreement shall be repealed and replaced by the following:

### Article 29
### Entitlement to Benefits
Notwithstanding other provisions of this Agreement, benefits under this Agreement shall not be granted with respect to an item of income or capital, taking into account all relevant facts and circumstances, if it is established that obtaining these benefits was one of the principal purposes of any arrangement or transaction that resulted directly or indirectly in the obtaining of those benefits, unless it is established that granting such benefits in these circumstances is in accordance with the purpose and objective of the relevant provisions of this Agreement.

## Article 6
1- The Protocol shall be subject to ratification in accordance with the procedures in force in Kuwait <orig>الكويت</orig> and Luxembourg. The two Contracting States shall notify each other in writing through diplomatic channels, upon the fulfillment of the applicable procedures.
2- The Protocol shall enter into force on the date of the later of the two notifications referred to in paragraph (1). This Protocol shall have effect with respect to taxable years

beginning on or after 1 January of the calendar year next following the year in which this Protocol enters into force.

### Protocol

amending the Convention between the Government of the Grand Duchy of
Luxembourg and the Government of the State of Kuwait for the avoidance of
double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion with respect to taxes on
income and on capital, signed at Luxembourg on 11th December 2007

The Government of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and the Government of the
State of Kuwait

Desiring to conclude a Protocol amending the Convention between the
Government of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and the Government of the State
of Kuwait for the avoidance of double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion
with respect to taxes on income and on capital, signed at Luxembourg on 11th
December 2007, (hereinafter referred to as "the Convention"), have agreed as
follows:

#### ARTICLE 1

The preamble of the Convention shall be deleted and replaced by the following:

"The Government of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and the Government of the
State of Kuwait

Desiring to further develop their economic relationship and to enhance their co-
operation in tax matters;

Intending to conclude a Convention for the elimination of double taxation with
respect to taxes on income and on capital without creating opportunities for non-
taxation or reduced taxation through tax evasion or avoidance (including through
treaty-shopping arrangements aimed at obtaining reliefs provided in this
Convention for the indirect benefit of residents of third States), have agreed as
follows:

#### ARTICLE 2

Paragraph 3 of Article 2 (Taxes Covered) of the Convention shall be deleted and
replaced by the following:

"3. The existing taxes to which this Convention shall apply are in particular:a) in the case of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg:
- (1) the income tax on individuals (l'impôt sur le revenu des personnes physiques);
- (2) the corporation tax (l'impôt sur le revenu des collectivités);
- (3) the capital tax (l'impôt sur la fortune); and
- (4) the communal trade tax (l'impôt commercial communal);
(hereinafter referred to as "Luxembourg tax").

## Explanatory Memorandum
## for Decree-Law No. 139 of 2025
## Approving a Memorandum of Understanding
## Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of India
## Regarding Cooperation in the Field of Defense

In a desire to develop and strengthen friendly relations and cooperation in the military field between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of India, through joint training, exchange of expertise, respect for the prevailing laws and regulations in both countries, and the enhancement of bilateral defense relations beneficial to both countries, a Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of India regarding cooperation in the field of defense was signed on 22/12/2024 in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig>.
In anticipation of this cooperation in the military field through joint training and exchange of expertise, in accordance with mutual respect for the prevailing systems and laws in both countries, a Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of India regarding cooperation in the field of defense was signed in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> on 22/12/2024.
Article (One) stipulated the purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding, which is to expand cooperation in defense matters in the field of military training and the exchange of military and civilian personnel in the field of military research and technology.
Article (Two) defined the areas of cooperation between the two parties in defense matters in accordance with international laws and their respective domestic legislations, including military cooperation between the armed forces, logistical cooperation between military technical and professional experts in various military fields, cooperation in combating terrorism, in the manufacture and supply of defense equipment, and other forms of cooperation, as well as any other areas agreed upon by the two parties within the framework of implementing the Memorandum of Understanding.
Article (Three) organized the principles of implementation by preparing an annual executive plan or a plan for an agreed-upon period for activities aimed at implementing the Memorandum of Understanding.
Article (Four) addressed the establishment of joint mechanisms and committees between the two parties for the purpose of promoting the objectives of the Memorandum of Understanding.
Article (Five) also specified the authorized agencies for implementing the Memorandum of Understanding between the two countries: the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig> of the Republic of India for the Government of the Republic of India, and the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig> of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> for the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>.
Article (Six) clarified the appropriate measures for protecting exchanged confidential information and documents, including the commitment of both parties to assign an equal degree of confidentiality to exchanged confidential information, documents, and materials,

Article (7) stipulated intellectual property rights, including that each party shall ensure appropriate protection for intellectual property rights resulting from their cooperation, in accordance with the laws of both countries. Furthermore, the publication of any documents arising from joint work under this Memorandum of Understanding shall be considered joint property, and the use of the name, logo, or official emblem of both parties on any publication, documents, or papers requires prior permission from both parties, and the official emblem shall not be misused.

Article (8) clarified that the provisions of this Memorandum shall not prejudice the laws in force between the two countries, nor shall they affect the rights and obligations of either party arising from other international treaties and agreements.

Article (9) regulated the financial arrangements such that each party shall be responsible for its own expenses for the purpose of implementing this Memorandum, unless otherwise agreed by the parties.

Article (10) referred to supplementary arrangements regarding any specific matter covered by the Memorandum of Understanding, whereby the parties may enter into a separate supplementary arrangement of a general or specific nature that would enhance the effective implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding.

Article (11) stipulated that in the event of any dispute or disagreement arising from the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum, the parties shall work to settle it amicably through consultations and negotiations. Furthermore, both parties shall continue to fulfill all obligations in accordance with the Memorandum of Understanding, unless these obligations constitute a point of dispute or disagreement.

Article (12) also clarified the provisions for the Memorandum's entry into force.

Article (13) outlined the method for amending the Memorandum of Understanding, whereby the parties may amend it by mutual written consent between the parties, in accordance with the procedures stipulated in the Memorandum of Understanding.

Finally, Article (14) reviewed the method for terminating this Memorandum.

Given that this Memorandum of Understanding serves the interests of both states and does not conflict with the obligations of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> in the Arab and international spheres.

And since this Memorandum of Understanding is considered among the agreements mentioned in the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, its approval shall therefore be by law in accordance with the provision of this paragraph.

And whereas the Amiri Decree <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024 AD, and its Article Four stipulated that laws shall be issued by decree-laws, a draft decree-law for its approval has therefore been prepared.

MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING
BETWEEN
THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT
AND
THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF INDIA
CONCERNING COOPERATION IN THE FIELD OF DEFENSE

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of India, hereinafter referred to individually as a "Party" and collectively as the "Parties";
Desiring to develop and strengthen friendly relations and mutual cooperation between the Parties to achieve the interests of their peoples, and to enhance bilateral defense relations that will be of mutual benefit to both countries;
Affirming their commitment to the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations;
And desiring to cooperate in the military field through joint training and exchange of expertise, while respecting the prevailing laws and regulations in both countries;
The Parties have reached the following understanding:

### ARTICLE 1
### PURPOSE
The purpose of this Memorandum of Understanding is to expand and develop cooperation in defense matters, which may include areas of military training, exchange of military and civilian personnel, cooperation, research, and military technology.

### ARTICLE 2
### AREAS OF COOPERATION
1. The Parties shall promote cooperation in defense matters in accordance with international laws and their respective national laws and legislations in any or all of the following areas:
a. Military education and training.
b. Military cooperation between armed forces.
c. Logistics cooperation between military personnel.

## Article 6
### Protection of Information
1. Both Parties shall undertake to accord an equal degree of confidentiality to the exchanged confidential information, documents, and materials, and the necessary security measures shall be taken in accordance with the appropriate regulatory laws and regulations.
2. The level of security protection for correspondence between the Parties shall be as follows:

<table_caption>Security Classification Levels for Correspondence Between Parties</table_caption>
<table>
| For the Republic of India | For the State of Kuwait |
|:---|:---|
| Top Secret | Top Secret |
| Secret | Secret |
| Confidential | Confidential |
| Restricted | Restricted |
</table>

3. Both Parties shall undertake not to transfer documents and information to any third party except with the prior written consent of the Party that issued such information.
4. The degree of confidentiality of documents and information shall be determined by the Party that issued them, and these documents and information shall be transferred through official governmental channels or through the armed forces agreed upon between the Parties.
5. No one shall be allowed to access the exchanged documents and information for the implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding, except for persons authorized by both Parties in accordance with regulatory legislation and regulations.

All confidential information shall remain the exclusive property of the disclosing party, and both parties shall remain committed not to use or disclose confidential information for any purpose other than the purposes specified by the disclosing party, and no intellectual property rights shall apply to the other party.
7. Undisclosed information, whether oral, written, or otherwise, which includes secrets of scientists or technicians and has not been exchanged in accordance with the provisions of this Memorandum of Understanding, shall not be transferred to any third party, unless otherwise agreed upon in writing by both parties.
8. Both parties are committed to protecting exchanged confidential documents and data even after the expiration of this Memorandum of Understanding.

### Article 7
### Intellectual Property Rights
1. Each party shall ensure appropriate protection for intellectual property rights resulting from cooperation under this Memorandum of Understanding, in accordance with their respective existing laws, rules, and regulations, and the multilateral agreements to which both parties are signatories.
2. In the event that research is conducted individually, and obtained by one of the parties or research results are obtained through a continuous effort by one of the parties, only the concerned party shall be granted the intellectual property right, unless otherwise agreed upon in writing by both parties.
3. In the event that research results are obtained through joint activities, intellectual property rights shall be granted jointly to both parties, and once granted to both parties, these rights shall become jointly owned by them.
4. Neither party may assign any rights or obligations arising from intellectual property rights resulting from these innovations and activities exchanged under this Memorandum of Understanding to any third party without the prior written consent of the other party.
5. In the event that research results are obtained through joint activities under this Memorandum of Understanding, both parties shall participate in the protection of intellectual property rights subject to their respective exclusive rights, and technological marketing in any other country shall be carried out through the conclusion of a separate agreement.

Any dispute or disagreement regarding the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding shall be settled amicably between the Parties through adequate consultation and exchange between the Parties. The dispute shall not be referred to a third party or to any international court or arbitration body for settlement.
2. Pending the settlement of the dispute or disagreement, the Parties shall continue to fulfill all obligations in accordance with this Memorandum of Understanding, unless such obligations constitute a point of dispute or disagreement.

### Article 12
**Entry into Force**
1. This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of the last written notification sent by one Party to the other concerning the completion of the necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force.
2. The provisions of this Memorandum shall remain in effect for a period of 5 years and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate this Memorandum of Understanding.

### Article 13
**Amendment**
The Parties may amend this Memorandum of Understanding by mutual written consent, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Memorandum of Understanding.

### Article 14
**Termination**
1. This Memorandum may be terminated if one Party notifies the other Party in writing of its desire to terminate this Memorandum, and the termination shall enter into force six (6) months from the date of receipt of the notification by the other Party.
2. In the event of the termination of this Memorandum, projects being implemented in accordance with this Memorandum shall remain in effect until their completion, unless the Parties agree otherwise.

cooperation between them to achieve the interests of their people, and
to foster the bilateral defense relations that will be of mutual benefit to
both countries,

Affirming their commitment to purposes and principles of the Charter
of the United Nations,

Aspiring to cooperate in the military field through joint training and
exchange of experiences while respecting the laws and regulations
prevailing in both the countries.

Have reached the following understanding:

Minister of Defense <orig>وزير الدفاع</orig>
State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
[Signature]
Hamad Jaber Al-Ali Al-Sabah <orig>حمد جابر العلي الصباح</orig>
Deputy Prime Minister <orig>نائب رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig>
# Article 1
## PURPOSE

The Purpose of this Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) is to
broaden and develop cooperation in Defense matters which can
include fields of Military Training, exchange of military and civilian
personnel and collaboration in military research and technology.

# Article 2
## COOPERATION SPHERES

1. The Parties shall promote cooperation in Defense matters in
accordance with the international laws and their respective national
laws and regulations in any or all of the following areas:
    a) The Military training and education.
    b) The Military cooperation among the Armed Forces.
    c) The Logistics Cooperation between military.
    d) Exchange of individuals and experts. Technicians and
    professionals in various military fields.
    e) Cooperation in the field of counter terrorism.
    f) Cooperation in the field of defense industry and equipment.
    g) Supply of Defense equipment/ material.
    h) Military development and research.
    i) Joint military exercises.
    j) Participating in Defense exhibition / show.
    k) Exchange for various military sports activities and in cultural
    and social fields.
    l) Humanitarian assistance and disaster Relief.
    m) International peacekeeping activities under UN mandate.
    n) Exchange of visits by ships and aircrafts.
    o) Cooperation in the area of Hydrography.
    p) Cooperation in maritime security.

### Article 6
### PROTECTION OF INFORMATION

1. The Parties shall commit themselves to giving an equal degree of confidentiality to the information, documents and confidential materials exchanged; the necessary security measures shall be taken in accordance with the appropriate national laws and regulations.

2. The level of security protection for correspondences between the Parties shall be as below;

<table_caption>Security Protection Levels for Correspondences between India and Kuwait</table_caption>
<table>
| For the Republic of India | For the State of Kuwait |
|:---|:---|
| Top Secret | Top Secret |
| Secret | Secret |
| Confidential | Confidential |
| Restricted | Restricted |
</table>

3. The Parties shall commit not to transfer the documents and the information to any third Party, except with a prior written approval from the Party who issued that information.

4. The degree of confidentiality of documents and information is determined by the Party who issued them, and these documents and information will be transmitted through the official Government Channels or through the Channels that are agreed upon between the Two Parties.

No one will be allowed to view the documents and the
information exchanged for the implementation of this MoU except the
persons who are authorized by the Two Parties in accordance with the
national legislation and regulations.

6. All confidential information shall remain the exclusive property
of the disclosing Party. The Parties agree that this MoU and the
disclosure of the confidential information do not grant or imply any
license, interest or right to the recipient in respect of any Intellectual
Property Right of the other Party.

7. Unpublished information, whether oral, in writing or otherwise,
discovered or conceived by the scientists or technicians and exchanged
under the provisions of this MoU will not be transmitted to a third
Party, unless otherwise agreed by the Parties in writing.

8. The Parties shall be bound to protect the confidential documents
and information exchanged, even after the termination of this MoU.

### Article 7
### INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS

1. Each Party shall ensure appropriate protection of Intellectual
Property Rights resulting from the cooperation under this MoU, in
accordance with the Laws, Rules, regulations and multilateral
Agreements to which both Parties are party to.

2. In the case of research being carried out solely and separately by
one of the parties or the results of the research obtained through a
separate effort of one of the parties, the party concerned only is granted
the Intellectual Property Right, and when it is granted this right it
becomes owned only by the party concerned.

either country or the rights or obligations of either Party arising out of
the treaties and international agreements to which either Party is
signatory to.

### Article 10
### SUPPLEMENTARY ARRANGEMENTS

With regard to any particular matter covered by the provisions of this MoU, the Parties may enter into separate supplementary arrangement of a general or specific nature as would, in their opinion, promote the effective implementation of the MoU.

### Article 11
### SETTLEMENT OF DISPUTES

1. Any dispute regarding the interpretation or implementation of this MoU will be settled amicably through mutual consultation and negotiation between the Parties. The dispute will not be referred to a Third Party or any other international court or tribunal for settlement.

2. While settling the dispute or difference, the Parties shall continue to fulfill all the obligations in accordance with this MoU, except if these obligations constitute a point of conflict or difference.

# Memorandum of Understanding for Cooperation between the Government of Kuwait
represented by the Public Authority for Housing Welfare <orig>المؤسسة العامة للرعاية السكنية</orig>
and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia represented by the Ministry of Municipal and Rural Affairs and Housing <orig>وزارة البلديات والإسكان</orig>

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the "Public Authority for Housing Welfare <orig>المؤسسة العامة للرعاية السكنية</orig>", and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, represented by the "Ministry of Municipal and Rural Affairs and Housing <orig>وزارة البلديات والإسكان</orig>", (hereinafter referred to as "the Parties"), out of their desire to encourage and enhance cooperation between them in the fields of the municipal sector and the housing sector, based on mutual respect, common interests, and equality, and in accordance with the systems, laws, and regulations in force in their respective countries, and according to the available capabilities, have agreed as follows:

## Article One
The Parties shall cooperate in any of the following areas:
1.  Urban Planning and Lands.
2.  Infrastructure.
3.  Cleanliness, Public Health, and Environmental Safety.
4.  Licenses and Permits.
5.  Municipal Control.
6.  Regulation of City Operators.
7.  Investment Asset Management.

State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>
Minister of State for Municipal Affairs <orig>وزير الدولة لشؤون البلدية</orig>
[Signature]
No original.
<page_end>98</page_end>

9. Stimulating housing supply and real estate development.

11. Community participation.
12. Any other area agreed upon by both parties.

### Article Two
The implementation of cooperation between the two parties shall be through the following means:
1. Exchange of information, expertise, and international best practices.
2. Exchange of visits between experts and specialists.
3. Organizing conferences, seminars, meetings, training sessions, courses, and workshops.
4. Any other means agreed upon by both parties.

### Article Three
The two parties shall work on developing joint executive cooperation programs for any of the areas of cooperation stipulated in this Memorandum, whenever the need arises.

### Article Four
The two parties shall take the necessary measures to protect intellectual property rights arising from the implementation of cooperation based on this Memorandum, in light of the systems and laws in force in their respective countries and the international agreements to which one or both of them are parties.

### Memorandum of Understanding

Between

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>

And

Concerning

Cooperation in the Field of Oil and Gas

</image>The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the United Arab Emirates <orig>دولة الإمارات العربية المتحدة</orig> (hereinafter collectively referred to as "the Parties"),
Desiring to strengthen the friendly relations existing between their countries and to expand bilateral cooperation between the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the United Arab Emirates <orig>دولة الإمارات العربية المتحدة</orig> on the basis of the principles of equality, mutual benefit, and full respect for their sovereignty,
And recognizing the benefit of enhancing cooperation between them in the field of oil and gas in advancing bilateral relations and cooperation between the two countries,
Have agreed as follows:

## Article (1)
### Objective of the Memorandum
This Memorandum of Understanding (the "Memorandum") aims to establish a framework for good faith cooperation in the field of oil and gas between the Parties and to facilitate the exchange of technical knowledge, advice, skills, and expertise between them.

## Article (2)
### Areas of Cooperation
The two parties shall cooperate in building close relations with relevant governmental bodies and private sector institutions, and between themselves in their respective countries, to cooperate in areas of mutual interest, including:
1.  Upstream oil and gas operations (exploration and production sector).
2.  Midstream sector (for oil and gas transportation and processing).
3.  Downstream oil and gas (refining and distribution sector).
4.  Petroleum products.

## Article (5)
### Funding and Applicable Law
The two Parties shall implement the cooperation activities stipulated in this Memorandum in accordance with the availability of financial budgets and in accordance with the laws, regulations, policies, and procedures applicable in their respective countries.

## Article (6)
### Costs and Expenses
The two Parties shall bear responsibility for their own costs and expenses incurred in the implementation of this Memorandum, unless otherwise agreed upon in writing by the Parties.

## Article (7)
### Confidentiality
The two Parties shall maintain the confidentiality of the information and content exchanged between them in relation to this Memorandum, and shall use such information and content solely for the purpose for which it was provided and for no other purpose.

# Article (9)
## Entry into Force, Amendment, Duration, and Termination

1.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Party informs the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels that it has fulfilled the constitutional and necessary procedures for its entry into force.
2.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in effect for a period of (5) years from the date of its entry into force and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate this Memorandum (6) months prior to its expiry date.
3.  This Memorandum of Understanding may be amended in writing by mutual agreement of the Parties at any time, and such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures set forth in the first paragraph of this Article.
4.  The termination of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect the validity or duration of any specific agreements, projects, and activities undertaken thereunder.

# Article (10)
## Supersession

This Memorandum of Understanding supersedes the Memorandum of Understanding for Cooperation in the Fields of Oil, Gas, Petrochemicals, and New and Renewable Energy Sources, signed between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the United Arab Emirates <orig>الإمارات العربية المتحدة</orig> on December 15, 2014.

Legal Affairs Department

# Memorandum of Understanding

Between

The Government of the State of Kuwait

And

The Government of the United Arab Emirates

For Cooperation in the Field of Promoting Direct Investment

State of Kuwait
Legal Affairs Department

Certified True Copy

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Kuwait Direct Investment Promotion Authority <orig>هيئة تشجيع الاستثمار المباشر</orig>, and the Government of the United Arab Emirates, represented by the Ministry of Investment <orig>وزارة الاستثمار</orig>, hereinafter referred to collectively as "the Parties" and individually as "the Party",

Desiring to strengthen the existing friendly relations between the two countries and to enhance bilateral cooperation between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the United Arab Emirates on the basis of equality, mutual interest, and full respect for sovereignty,

Recognizing that strengthening investment cooperation between the two countries will benefit the advancement of bilateral relations and cooperation between them,

Have agreed as follows:

### Article (1)

This Memorandum of Understanding aims to establish a framework for investment cooperation based on good faith between the Parties to facilitate the sharing of technical knowledge, advice, skills, and expertise in the field of promoting direct investment.

### Article (2)

The two parties shall cooperate with each other according to a timeline to be agreed upon between them later to achieve the following:
1. Exchange statistical information regarding direct investments and available business opportunities, and make this information accessible to the business communities in both countries with the aim of increasing mutual investments.
2. Exchange legal and regulatory information related to direct investment opportunities and developments in the investment environment between the two countries.

### Article (4)
The two Parties shall cooperate in developing exhibitions, workshops, conferences, and other events aimed at expanding cooperation in the field of direct investment.

### Article (5)
The two Parties shall facilitate and encourage business missions between the two countries to explore prospects for cooperation in all areas of direct investment.

### Article (6)
The two Parties shall appoint a focal point for the purpose of implementing this Memorandum of Understanding, and the focal point's information shall be exchanged in writing through diplomatic channels.

### Article (7)
The two Parties shall (in accordance with the internal rules and laws of each Party) not disclose any confidential documents, information, or data provided by the other Party or derived from the implementation of this Memorandum to a third party, and the provisions of this Article shall remain in effect even after the termination of this Memorandum.

## Article (8)
1.  This Memorandum of Understanding does not represent any legal or financial obligations on either Party.
2.  Each Party shall bear the costs and expenses related to its own activities in accordance with the provisions of this Memorandum, and neither Party shall be responsible for the costs and expenses incurred by the other Party.

## Article (9)
Any disputes arising between the Parties regarding the interpretation or implementation of this Memorandum of Understanding shall be settled amicably through diplomatic channels.

## Article (10)
1.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Party informs the other Party, in writing and through diplomatic channels, of its fulfillment of the necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force.
2.  This Memorandum of Understanding may be amended in writing by agreement of the Parties, at any time. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures set forth in the first paragraph of this Article.
3.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in force for a period of (5) years from the date of its entry into force, and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate this Memorandum (6) months prior to its expiry date.
4.  The termination of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect the validity or duration of any specific agreements, projects, and activities undertaken in connection with this Memorandum of Understanding.

Investment Promotion Authority and The Government of the Hong
Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of

### Paragraph 3

The Participants will support and facilitate each other's incoming missions and business programmes and, in this regard, will help to recommend and organize relevant meetings where possible and appropriate.

### Paragraph 4

A Participant will support and cooperate with the other Participant in organizing investment promotion events and activities, that foster bilateral investment between the State of Kuwait and the Hong Kong SAR.

### Paragraph 5

This Memorandum of Understanding does not create any legal obligation or binding commitment on either Participant.

### Paragraph 6

The activities conducted under this Memorandum of Understanding will be carried out by each Participant subject to its laws and regulations and the limits of its competence and available resources.

### Paragraph 7

1- This Memorandum of Understanding will come into effect on the date of receipt of the last notification in which one of the Participants notifies the other, in writing, and through official channels, informing that it has completed the legal procedures necessary for its carrying out of this Memorandum of Understanding.

## Annex B

# PROTOCOL
### Amending the Air Transport Services Agreement
### Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan
### Signed on January 19, 2004

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan <orig>جمهورية أوزبكستان</orig> (hereinafter referred to as "the Contracting Parties"),

Pursuant to Article (16) of the Air Transport Services Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan <orig>جمهورية أوزبكستان</orig>, signed on January 19, 2004 (hereinafter referred to as "the Agreement"), and recognizing the importance of developing air transport services between the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Republic of Uzbekistan <orig>جمهورية أوزبكستان</orig>,

Have agreed as follows:

## Article 1

The Contracting Parties shall, through friendly consultations, reach an agreement to amend and supplement the Agreement as follows:

1.  Paragraph (c) of Article (1) of the Agreement shall read as follows:
    "Designated airline" means any airline or airlines designated in writing by one Contracting Party to the other Contracting Party in accordance with Article (3) of this Agreement as the airline entitled to operate the agreed services on the specified routes in accordance with Article (2) of this Agreement.

Article (3) of the Agreement shall read as follows:
1) Each Contracting Party shall have the right to designate in writing to the other Contracting Party one or more air transport enterprises for the purpose of operating the agreed services on the specified routes in accordance with this Agreement, and to withdraw or replace such designation.

2) Upon receipt of such designation, and the request of the designated air transport enterprise in the manner and procedure followed for an operating authorization and technical license, each Contracting Party shall grant the appropriate authorization for operation with the least possible delay in procedures, for the exercise of the rights specified in Article (2) of this Agreement, provided that the following are met:
a. The principal place of business of the air transport enterprise is in the territory of the Contracting Party designating that enterprise, and
b. The regulatory and effective control of the air transport enterprise is under the authority of that Contracting Party, and that enterprise holds a valid Air Operator Certificate (AOC) <orig>شهادة مشغل جوي (ش.م.ج)</orig> issued by the Contracting Party designating it, and
c. The Contracting Party designating the air transport enterprise applies the provisions specified in Article (14) and Article (15) of this Agreement, and
d. The designated air transport enterprise must be qualified to fulfill the conditions imposed upon it under the laws and regulations normally applied to the operation of international air transport routes by the Contracting Party receiving the designation.

3. Upon receipt of the operating authorization contained in paragraph (2) of this Article, the designated air transport enterprise may at any time commence operation of the agreed routes for which it has been designated, provided that the air transport enterprise applies the provisions in force in this Agreement.
4. Article (4) of the Agreement shall read as follows:
1) The aeronautical authorities of each Contracting Party shall have the right to revoke the authorizations referred to in Article (3) of this Agreement concerning an air transport enterprise designated by the other Contracting Party, or to cancel, suspend, or impose conditions on such authorization, temporarily or permanently, in the event that:
a. The designated air transport enterprise is unable to meet its obligations at its principal place of business in the territory of the Contracting Party that designated it. Or

</footer># Decree No. 176 of 2025
## Amending Certain Provisions of Decree No. 391 of 2010
## Regarding the Establishment of the Kuwait Academy of Arts <orig>أكاديمية الكويت للفنون</orig>

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Law No. 15 of 1979 regarding Civil Service <orig>الخدمة المدنية</orig>, and its amending laws,
- And the Decree issued on 7 Jumada al-Awwal 1399 AH corresponding to 4 April 1979 AD regarding the Civil Service System <orig>نظام الخدمة المدنية</orig>, and its amending laws,
- And Decree No. 391 of 2010 regarding the Establishment of the Kuwait Academy of Arts <orig>أكاديمية الكويت للفنون</orig>, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research <orig>وزير التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
We have decreed the following:

### Article One
The texts of Articles (4/First Paragraph and Second Paragraph) and (6) of the aforementioned Decree No. 391 of 2010 shall be replaced with the following texts:
**Article (4/First Paragraph and Second Paragraph):**
The Academy's management shall be overseen by a Board of Trustees <orig>مجلس أمناء</orig> chaired by the Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research <orig>وزير التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي</orig> and comprising:
1- The Director General <orig>مدير عام</orig> of the Academy
2- The Secretary General <orig>الأمين العام</orig> of the National Council for Culture, Arts and Letters <orig>المجلس الوطني للثقافة والفنون والآداب</orig>.
<page_end>133</page_end>

3- Deans of Institutes
4- Three public figures in the field of arts.
The members of the Board of Trustees mentioned in paragraphs (3/4) shall be appointed by a decision of the Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research <orig>وزير التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي</orig> for a renewable term of four years.
**Article (6):**
The Academy shall be managed by a Director General <orig>مدير عام</orig>, who shall be selected from among the academic staff of the Academy or from outside it, holding the rank of professor, for a renewable term of four years, renewable once, to oversee its scientific, administrative, and financial affairs, assisted by a sufficient number of qualified academic staff and employees.
The appointment of the Director General <orig>المدير العام</orig> and the determination of their competencies shall be issued by a decision of the Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research <orig>وزير التعليم العالي والبحث العلمي</orig>, and their financial allocations shall be determined by a decision of the Civil Service Commission <orig>مجلس الخدمة المدنية</orig>.

### Article Two
The phrase "based on the proposal of the Institute's Council" contained in paragraph 3 of Article (5) of Decree No. 391 of 2010 <orig>المرسوم رقم 391 لسنة 2010</orig> referred to, shall be deleted, and the phrase "one of his assistants or" contained in Article (7) of the same Decree shall also be deleted.

### Article Three
Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree, which shall come into effect from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Cabinet Decision
## No. 1113 of 2025
### Regarding the Withdrawal of Kuwaiti Citizenship Certificates
### From Certain Individuals

The Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>
- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qa'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Article (21 bis "A") of Amiri Decree No. 15 of 1959 regarding the Kuwaiti Nationality Law, and its amending laws,
- And based on the presentation of the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior,

Has decided

### Article One
The Kuwaiti citizenship certificate shall be withdrawn from those mentioned below, and Kuwaiti nationality shall be withdrawn from anyone who acquired it through dependency on the holder of that certificate:
1. Mubarak Saleh Ali Attallah Al-Ajmi <orig>مبارك صالح علي عطا الله العجمي</orig>.
2. Mohammed Hamad Manahi Ayedh Al-Ajmi <orig>محمد حمد مناحي عايض العجمي</orig>.
3. Nasser Hamad Manahi Ayedh Al-Ajmi <orig>ناصر حمد مناحي عايض العجمي</orig>.
4. Ali Abdullah Jaber Siraj Ibrahim Al-Ajmi <orig>علي عبدالله جابر سراج إبراهيم العجمي</orig>.
5. Siraj Abdullah Jaber Siraj Ibrahim Al-Ajmi <orig>سراج عبدالله جابر سراج إبراهيم العجمي</orig>.
6. Obaid Salem Fallah Fadghoush Al-Hajri <orig>عبيد سالم فلاح فدغوش الهاجري</orig>.
7. Mubarak Dhwaihi Ayedh Saad Al-Hajri <orig>مبارك ضويحي عايض سعد الهاجري</orig>.
8. Mufleh Mash'a Awadh Harees Al-Mutairi <orig>مفلح ماشع عواض حريص المطيري</orig>.

### Article Two
The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Interior shall implement this decision, which shall be effective from the date of its issuance and published in the Official Gazette.

Prime Minister
Ahmed Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>

- Based on the recommendation of the Committee for Setting Standards and Identifying Higher Education Institutions in Medical Specialties and Programs Outside the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> at its sixty-first meeting held on July 29, 2025.
- Based on the recommendation of the Committee for Proposing Standards, Reviewing, and Updating Lists of Higher Education Institutions Outside the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> at its tenth meeting held on August 10, 2025.
- And upon the presentation of the Director General <orig>مدير عام</orig> of the National Bureau for Academic Accreditation and Education Quality Assurance <orig>الجهاز الوطني للاعتماد الأكاديمي وضمان جودة التعليم</orig>.
- And as required by the public interest.
(It is decided)
### Article One
Adding the following academic programs and degrees to Ministerial Resolution No. (2020/40) issued on February 17, 2020, regarding the updated list of higher education institutions approved for enrollment in Bachelor's and postgraduate programs in the United Kingdom:

<table_caption>Approved Academic Programs and Degrees in the United Kingdom</table_caption>
<table>
| University Name | Specialization | Degree |
|:---|:--------|:---|
| University of Cambridge | Biomedical Science | M |
| University of Aberdeen | Economics | M, D |
| University of Exeter | Education | D |
</table>

### Article Two
The study program to be joined by students must follow the traditional education system, and studies must be conducted through regular attendance during the academic week.

### Article Three
The study program to be joined by students must have completed the specified study period for granting the academic degree, by graduating the first batch from the college offering this program.

### Article Four
The Master's program must not be an executive program.

### Article Five
The regulations governing enrollment and the study system in higher education institutions outside the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> must be observed, and it must be ensured that academic degrees have met the requirements for their acquisition in accordance with the regulations issued by the Ministry of Higher Education <orig>وزارة التعليم العالي</orig> in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>.

### Article Six:
This resolution shall be effective from its date of issuance, and any text contradicting its provisions shall be repealed. It shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

### Article Seven:
The competent authorities shall be informed and act accordingly.

## Ministry of Social Affairs <orig>وزارة الشئون الاجتماعية</orig>
### Ministerial Resolution No. (203) of 2025
Amending the Regulation of Cooperative Work <orig>لائحة تنظيم العمل التعاوني</orig> issued by Ministerial Resolution No. (46/T) of 2021
Minister of Family and Childhood Affairs <orig>وزير الشئون الأسرية والطفولة</orig>:
- Having reviewed Decree-Law No. (24) of 1979 concerning Cooperative Societies <orig>الجمعيات التعاونية</orig>, as amended by Law No. (118) of 2013.
- And Decree No. (50) of 2017 concerning the Ministry of Social Affairs <orig>وزارة الشئون الاجتماعية</orig>.
- And Cabinet Resolution No. (193) at its meeting No. (2023/7) held on 6/2/2023.
- And Ministerial Resolution No. (165/T) of 2013 regarding the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> of Decree-Law No. (24) of 1979 concerning Cooperative Societies <orig>الجمعيات التعاونية</orig>, as amended by Law No. (118) of 2013 and its amendments.
- And Ministerial Resolution No. (166/T) of 2013 regarding the Model Articles of Association <orig>النظام الأساسي النموذجي</orig> for Cooperative Societies <orig>الجمعيات التعاونية</orig> and its amendments.
- And Ministerial Resolution No. (68) of 2023 regarding the amendment of the Annex to the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> of Decree-Law No. (24) of 1979 concerning Cooperative Societies <orig>الجمعيات التعاونية</orig>, amended by Law No. (118) of 2013 and issued by Ministerial Resolution No. (165/T) of 2013.
- And upon the presentation of the Undersecretary <orig>وكيل الوزارة</orig>.
- And as required by the public interest.
((Resolved))
### Article (1):
Articles (49 to 54) of the Regulation of Cooperative Work <orig>لائحة تنظيم العمل التعاوني</orig> issued by Ministerial Resolution No. (46/T) of 2021 and amended by Ministerial Resolution No. (68) of 2013 shall be replaced by the following articles:
#### Chapter Four: Employment
### Article (49)
Without prejudice to the national labor ratios in cooperative societies <orig>الجمعيات التعاونية</orig> as determined by Cabinet resolutions, the society must follow a prudent appointment policy, whereby appointments are limited to the necessary extent for the society to perform its work according to its actual needs, and the ratio of salaries, excluding supervisory positions, to sales shall not exceed (6%), calculated according to the latest financial report, without including exceptional sales periods. Appointments may exceed this ratio if the employment aims to meet the specified national labor ratio, or in the event of opening new branches and sales outlets for the society, or if the society needs to appoint an internal auditor.

## Article (50)
The following conditions must be met to fill supervisory positions:
- The candidate must be of Kuwaiti nationality.
- Must have a good reputation, commendable conduct and behavior, and must not have been previously convicted of a felony or a crime involving breach of honor or trust, unless their reputation has been restored.
- Must not have been a former member of the board of directors of a cooperative society that was dissolved or dismissed for committing serious financial and administrative violations, unless the legal periods stipulated in Article (35) of the Law have passed since the dissolution or dismissal decision.
- Must not be retired for any reason.
- Must successfully pass the admission tests and personal interview according to the appointment mechanism specified by the Ministry.
- Must submit their resignation from their current employer if finally accepted.
- Must hold appropriate academic qualifications from a government or private university inside or outside Kuwait, duly attested, or from institutes accredited by the Ministry of Higher Education / Wizarat Al-Ta'leem Al-'Ali <orig>وزارة التعليم العالي</orig>.
- Submit an application to fill a supervisory position through the (Fakharna) platform at the Public Authority for Manpower / Al-Hay'a Al-'Amma Lil-Quwa Al-'Amila <orig>الهيئة العامة للقوى العاملة</orig>.
- Possess the experience indicated for each position in the following table:

## Resolution No. (74) of 2025
Regarding the acquisition by Saudi Fransi Capital <orig>السعودي الفرنسي كابيتال</orig> (Kingdom of Saudi Arabia) of 19.35% of the capital of MyFatoorah Company <orig>شركة ماي فاتورة</orig> for providing electronic payment services (Kuwait).
Chairman of the Board of Directors:
Having reviewed:
- Law No. (72) of 2020 regarding Competition Protection,
- Decree No. (238) of 2017 appointing members of the Board of Directors of the Competition Protection Agency <orig>جهاز حماية المنافسة</orig>,
- Resolution No. (14) of 2021 issuing the Executive Regulations of Law No. (72) of 2020 regarding Competition Protection, and their amendments,
- Economic Concentration Process No. (CPACNM000242025) regarding the acquisition by Saudi Fransi Capital <orig>السعودي الفرنسي كابيتال</orig> (Kingdom of Saudi Arabia) of 19.35% of the capital of MyFatoorah Company <orig>شركة ماي فاتورة</orig> for providing electronic payment services (Kuwait),
- The Executive Management's report regarding the aforementioned economic concentration process,
- The approval of the Board of Directors in its meeting No. (103) held on 26/8/2025.
- And based on the exigencies of work.
It has been decided
Article One: Approval of Economic Concentration Process No. (CPACNM000242025), in accordance with the following terms and obligations:
1) Obligating the concentration parties to provide the Agency <orig>الجهاز</orig> within one month from the date of completion of the transaction with copies of their contract templates with customers, provided that the provisions of the Competition Protection Law are observed.
2) Obligating the concentration parties not to impose any form of refusal to deal, withholding products, hindering competition, or tying products by suspending the conclusion of a contract or agreement on terms of accepting obligations that are not related to the subject of the transaction.
3) Obligating the concentration parties to the principle of equal opportunities among competitors and non-discrimination between customers in contractual terms without justification.
4) Subjecting the concentration parties to continuous monitoring and evaluation by the Agency <orig>الجهاز</orig> for a period of one year regarding the prices and quality of the services provided.
Article Two: The competent authorities – each within its jurisdiction – shall implement this resolution, notify all parties of this resolution, and it shall be effective from the date of its issuance.
Chairman of the Board of Directors

# Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig>
## Resolution No. (178 / R) of 2025
Governor of the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig>
Having reviewed Articles (21) and (61) of Law No. (32) of 1968 concerning Currency, the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig>, and the Regulation of the Banking Profession, and its amendments.
And Articles (4), (5), and (7) of Ministerial Resolution No. (40) of 2003 concerning the Regulations of the Register of Islamic Banks at the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig>.
And based on the request of Boubyan Bank <orig>بنك بوبيان</orig> dated 2025/8/18 regarding the amendment of its data in the Register of Islamic Banks at the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig>.

Has decided:
### Article One
The following amendment shall be recorded in the Register of Islamic Banks at the Central Bank of Kuwait <orig>بنك الكويت المركزي</orig> regarding Boubyan Bank's <orig>بنك بوبيان</orig> data:
Appointment of Mr. Bader Adel Al-Abduljader <orig>بدر عادل العبد الجادر</orig> from Al-Aiban, Al-Osaimi & Partners (Ernst & Young) as the Bank's auditor for the fiscal year ending on 2025/12/31, replacing Mr. Abdul Karim Abdullah Al-Sa'dan <orig>عبد الكريم عبدالله السعدان</orig> from the same office.

### Article Two
This resolution shall be published in the Official Gazette and shall be effective from the date of its issuance.
Al-Hafiz <orig>الحافظ</orig>

# Explanatory Memorandum
for Decree-Law No. 130 of 2025
Approving the Agreement on the Payment Systems Interconnection System
Between the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> States

Stemming from the objectives of the Basic Statute of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربي</orig> to strengthen stronger ties between the GCC <orig>مجلس التعاون</orig> states and develop cooperation relations among them in various fields, and in line with the Economic Agreement of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> aiming to enhance the economies of the Council states in light of global economic developments.
And based on the Supreme Council's decision in its thirty-seventh session regarding the approval of establishing and building a payment systems interconnection system in the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> states, the Agreement on the Payment Systems Interconnection System between the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> states was signed on 16/2/2022.

Article (3) addressed general provisions.
Articles (4), (5), and (6) clarified the powers of the Committee of Governors, the duties and powers of the Central Banks, and the protection of payment, settlement, and clearing, and indicated that clearing arrangements are exempt from the provisions of bankruptcy laws in the Council states.
Article (7) clarified the provisions for immunity and tax exemptions applicable to the assets of companies established under Clause (1) of Article (5), their board members, and employees, as well as travel and residency facilities enabling them to perform their duties in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in each state.
Articles (8) and (9) stipulated confidentiality of information and the method for settling disputes arising from this Agreement.
Articles (10) and (11) addressed withdrawal from the Agreement, and termination or suspension of membership of a party if it breaches any of the provisions or system of the Agreement.
Article (12) included provisions for interpretation, whereby the Committee of Governors is responsible for interpreting the provisions of this Agreement, and its decisions shall be binding.
Articles (13) and (14) referred to the amendment of the Agreement and its entry into force, stating that the Agreement shall be effective from the date of deposit of the second state's ratification instrument with the General Secretariat of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>.
Since this Agreement serves the interest of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and does not conflict with its obligations in the Arab and international spheres.
And whereas this Agreement is considered one of the agreements that, according to its provisions, requires ratification by law in accordance with the text of the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, and based on Article Four of the Amiri Order issued on 10/5/2024, a draft Decree-Law approving it, along with its explanatory memorandum, has been prepared and attached in the appropriate legal format.

## Agreement on the Payment Systems Interconnection System
Between the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> States
August 2020 AD

### Preamble
The Member States of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>;
*   The United Arab Emirates <orig>دولة الإمارات العربية المتحدة</orig>,
*   The Kingdom of Bahrain <orig>مملكة البحرين</orig>,
*   The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>,
*   The Sultanate of Oman <orig>سلطنة عمان</orig>,
*   The State of Qatar <orig>دولة قطر</orig>,
*   The State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>;
And stemming from the objectives of the Basic Statute of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> calling for closer rapprochement and stronger ties between the Council states and for the importance of developing existing cooperation relations among them in various fields, and in affirmation of the foundations and principles established by the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>.
And in line with the Economic Agreement of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> aiming to enhance the economies of the Council states in light of global economic developments and to strengthen their competitive capabilities,
And based on the Supreme Council's decision in its thirty-seventh session (Manama - 6-7 December 2016 AD) regarding the approval of establishing and building a payment systems interconnection system in the Council states, and authorizing the monetary institutions and central banks in the Council states to own and manage
Where Articles (1) and (2) contained definitions and objectives of the Agreement, the most prominent of which were the establishment of a system linking payment and settlement systems between the Council states, enhancing the safety and efficiency of joint Gulf payment systems, and establishing the supervisory and regulatory powers of central banks over payment systems and working on their development.

the project through the establishment of an independent company owned and valued by the monetary institutions and central banks of the Council states, they have agreed as follows:

### Article (1)
#### Definitions
For the purpose of applying the provisions of this Agreement, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings assigned to each of them, unless the context otherwise requires:
**Council States**: The Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> states.
**Central Banks**: The monetary institutions, banks, and central banks of the Council States.
**Governors' Committee**: The committee formed by the governors of the Central Banks.
**System**: A system that links the payment systems of the Council States and other entities approved to participate in the System to facilitate and settle payments and execute cross-border payment orders, including the tools, procedures, and rules for financial transfers between participants.
**Operator**: The entity that has been or is being established or appointed in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement to manage and operate the System or one of its components.
**Participant**: Any party permitted to exchange, clear, or settle through the System with other participants, whether directly or indirectly.
**Settlement**: The actual execution of participants' rights and obligations by transferring funds or securities.
**Clearing**: The exchange and confirmation of payment orders and the determination of the net rights and obligations of any participant for the purpose of settlement.

### Article (2)
#### Objectives
This Agreement aims to achieve the following:
1.  Establish a system that links payment and settlement systems among the Council States to execute payment transfers and settlement operations and payment orders between them.
2.  Enhance the safety and efficiency of joint Gulf payment systems to mitigate any potential risks, thereby preserving financial stability in the participating Council States and serving their interests.
3.  Establish the supervisory and regulatory powers of the Central Banks over payment systems among the Council States, and work towards their development.
4.  Enhance and develop automated clearing operations and procedures agreed upon by the Central Banks.
5.  Establish and maintain the integrity of a regional infrastructure to serve as the foundation for joint payment systems among the Council States, through the following:
    a. Provide a real-time cross-border settlement system for the Council States.
    b. Support transactions in the local currencies of the Council States and financial settlement operations between the Central Banks.
    c. Enhance integration among financial markets, ensure the speed of completing cash transfers, standardize their format, guarantee their protection, and support bilateral and multilateral trade relations.

### Article (3)
#### General Provisions
1.  The System shall provide payment settlement and clearing services in the currencies of the Council States, and in currencies that the Governors' Committee <orig>لجنة المحافظين</orig> deems appropriate to include from time to time. The System shall support operations with Central Bank funds after obtaining guarantees as determined by the Governors' Committee <orig>لجنة المحافظين</orig>.
2.  Central Banks that may be affected by any action violating the provisions of this Agreement may find alternative solutions to ensure the settlement of transactions.
3.  The participation of Council States in the System shall be optional, based on each state's readiness, and is not linked to contributing to the establishment of any Gulf payment company.

### Article (4)
#### Powers of the Governors' Committee
To achieve the objectives of this Agreement, the Governors' Committee <orig>لجنة المحافظين</orig> shall have the necessary powers to achieve these objectives, and in particular, it shall have the following:
1.  Establish the regulatory, supervisory, and governance frameworks for the System.
2.  Approve the necessary terms, rules, and controls for the appointment and licensing of the System operator, and for the operation and management of the System, including business continuity.
3.  Approve the financial and accounting controls for the System.
4.  Approve the fees and tariffs related to the System.
5.  Define and establish the regulatory and operational policies and rules for settlement and clearing operations.
6.  Approve the necessary policies and rules for determining the finality and irrevocability of payment, settlement, and clearing operations.
7.  Establish regulatory, supervisory, and executive committees, and define their jurisdictions, tasks, and responsibilities.
8.  Approve the rules, terms, and controls for participation in the System.
9.  Work towards developing the rules and regulations related to Gulf payment systems.
10. Approve the linking of the System with similar regional and international systems.
11. Establish a work system for the Governors' Committee <orig>لجنة المحافظين</orig> and its governance.
12. Approve the necessary terms, rules, and controls related to the prohibition, suspension, and default of participants in the System.

### Article (5)
#### Tasks and Powers of the Central Banks
To achieve the objectives of this Agreement, the Central Banks shall have the following tasks and powers:
1.  Establish, own, and appoint companies to manage and operate the System in accordance with the controls approved by the Governors' Committee <orig>لجنة المحافظين</orig>.
2.  Participate in the System in accordance with the approved terms, rules, and controls.
3.  Work towards developing payment systems in a manner that keeps pace with the latest methods and practices, and ensure the operation and continuity of the System and its related services in accordance with the approved terms, rules, and controls.
4.  Ensure the settlement of transactions executed through the System in accordance with the approved terms, rules, and controls, including finding alternative methods to ensure this in case of operator failure or non-provision of service, in accordance with the relevant rules and procedures necessary to achieve this.
5.  Approve the exchange rate between the currencies of the Council States and other currencies for transactions within the System.
